text:
I didn't take any extra notes when I tried this beer for the first time but I'm gonna try it again and update my comments.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

from notes (2012 or 2013).
good toast and grassy hop forward impy pils. body is ok, a little heavy for the style. Id get again (havent seen in a while, though)...

Bottle at 2nd tuesday tasting. Botlle is quite old so it pours clear golden with no head. Aroma is sweet, bit chemical and dusty. Taste is quite sweet with a faint bitterness still present in the background. Have to try this one fresh.

Bottle, three years old out something like that. Pours a headless, clear yellow beer. Aroma has tones of madeira, faint hops. Nice to see that the hops are still vaguely present after all these years. Quite sweet, alcoholic. Good to try fresh.

Bottle shared at De Molen tasting.  Pours clear light golden with no real head.  Aroma of caramel, spice, nutmeg, some light vanilla.  Flavour is over moderate sweet and bitter.  Medium to full bodied with soft carbonation.

Bottle shared at the molen monthly tasting.
Almost no head.  Clear golden pour.  Nice bitterness.  Well balanced
Bottle @ 2nd tuesday tasting. Aroma is strong malt, some thinner and very faint hops. Flavour has some bitterness, creamy malt note, some bitter hops. Faded, but still not bad.

Bottle at monthly 2nd Tuesday tasting @ De Molen, hosted by dEnk. Hazy golden pour, thin white head. A bit too old bottle. Aroma is fruity, honey, crispy but definitely not fresh anymore hops. Flavor is sweetish sugary malts, slightly chemical, some madeira. Should re-rate fresh.

Pours murky golden orange with a thick off white head.  Nose is citrus orange, spice like nutmeg and some light pine.  Taste is sweet with a decent amount of bitter, but I remember having this sometime ago and thinking it was more bitter than this.  Could be this is an old bottle as there is no brewed on date.  Mouthfeel is crisp, clean, heavy body and a long finish.

Bottle, Pours a cloudy glowing color, very good lacing anf head with awesome bubbles throughout. Aromas of earthy grains, heavy german malts, and lemon. Taste gives off some serious heat, almost vodka. Notes of grapes, corn, and pepper.

A - Pours a clear golden-orange with a finger of frothy white head atop. Head fades down at a normal pace leaving behind some light lace.

S - Aroma is a mix of bread and grain with some citrus hops, some sweetness, and a touch of pine.

T - Starts off with some sweet grain and bread with some citrus hop and bitterness. Through the middle, some more sweet malt comes through with a touch of pine. The finish is a mix of sweet malt, grain, biscuit, bitterness, and a touch of booze.

M - Medium-plus bodied with moderate carbonation. Feels smooth with a sweet and warming finish.

D - Pretty drinkable. Feels a bit rough and a bit warm. Needed some more flavors to balance out the body and booze.
Bottle @ Monks Sveavägen. Golden colour with a large head. Sweet fruity aroma. Sweet taste with some bitterness.

Pours a golden color with a large head to it. Has a fruity yeast smell to it thats pretty nice. Taste is somewhat similar and has a nice bitterness through out. Has a long after taste that is very pleasant.

Aroma is bread, yeast and lemons/bananas.  The flavor is essentially what the description for the beer is, a super-charged German Pilsner, with a bitter, slightly alcoholic finish.  Pretty good overall, the alcohol was noticeable but didnt overpower the flavor.

Bottle from South Bay Drugs: Once poured, a large thick foamy head quickly becomes alive and the carbonation rises through the clear straw blonde color. In the nose, a decked out sour notes of grass, earthy hops and oddly enough a whiff of pumpkin or squash? The flavor is strong with European style lager qualities such as grassy hops, grained malts and a zesty strain of yeast.

Bottle: &nbsp Hazy straw, golden hued, thin whispy white head, spotty lacing. &nbsp Bright hoppy straw nose. 

&nbsp Soft mealiness. &nbsp Grassy like a Pilsner, but also fairly hoppy like a Pale or an IPA. &nbsp Fairly well 

balanced. &nbsp Clean, lingering hop bite. &nbsp Has a noticeable amount of heat on it. &nbsp Body and mouthfeel are 

moderate to full. &nbsp Almost picks up more bitterness after the finish. &nbsp The grassiness dies, but the hops 

linger. &nbsp Tongue still thinks its a little too mealy. &nbsp Not sure how it couldnt be considering its trying to 

be balanced out with this bitterness. &nbsp Interesting beer. &nbsp It works, but not one I would ask for again. &nbsp 

I like these two beers kept seperate.
Pours a hazy golden orange with a white head. Aroma is sweet, light grain, and fruit. Flavor is sweet malt, lightly bready, citrusy /  fruity hop, thick in the mouth with a lightly bitter finish.

Poured up on tap at Papago with deep clear gold with near bright white head. The aroma has big spicy hop notes as well as a bit of floral hops and sweet malts. The taste is full hop forward with flavor hops and firm bitter hops like floral then robust levels of spicy hops and heading into bitter hop resin while a modest sweet citrus hop and pear cotton candy is noticed. This is fully hop forward with floral hops that are at just the right modest to moderate level for my taste and yummy spicy hops are basically in charge.
Lemon aroma accents the lager character, and an oyster edge that doesnt distract.  Big citrus pils, beautiful character that has a <???> center and a biting hoppy edge.
On tap at the brewery with the bros for dallas bachelor party.  Nice dark gold color.  Dry but fruity pils... Some mango notes.  Good for style, but not my thing.

Poured a rich orange color with a good sized creamy white head and decent lacing. Nose is fruity.  Medium body with a smooth and pleasant mouthfeel. The flavor is fruit, floral hops and and there is a light bitter finish.  Alcohol is clearly  present .  Overall everything works together for a tasty and enjoyable brew..

[On tap @ brewery] Lightly clouded orangey amber, modest head formation. Nose is predominant malt and grain, not as much hop as expected. Soft grainy malts, hops come through on the palate adding a nice bitter balance, but still not as forceful as expected. Needed a little more carbonation and slightly colder temperature.
Pouts a golden yellow colour with a little white lacing. Nice aroma of caramel and toffee. Taste of etoh, malt and some hop citrus. A nicely balanced beer and easy to drink I like this one!

22oz bottle in a shaker.  Pours golden with a fluffy, off-white head.  Aroma strong of caramel malts with spicy, floral hops.  The same flavor.  Average texture.  A very hoppy, full-bodied pilsner, but still a pilsner
Bottle @ Pikkulintu, Helsinki. Originally rated on 28.1.2010. Hoppy, but otherwise quite generic pilsner.
Golden yellow pour with a large white head. Aroma is malty. Taste is malty and sweet with a definite hop presence, and a dry finish. Very good but not as drinkable with the high abv.
Clear golden with a big white head. Aroma is sweet, malty and moderate hoppy - fruit and cats piss. Flavor is quite sweet and very bitter. Dry and rather bitter finish. 010711

In short: A very sweet/sugary and somewhat boozy pilsner on steroids.  Too harsh.
How: Bottle 22oz.  Consumed fresh (probably fresh) one week after purchase
The look: Cloudy yellow blonde body topped by a large white head with excellent retention
In long: Nose is moderately dry-grass with notes of a fresh baguette and sweet white cake.  Taste is loaded with pale malts and what appears to be sugary crystal malts.  Flavor of white bread baguette topped with fresh banana slices and with a lot of refined white sugar spread all over it.  Also notes of pineapples.  Then comes the dry grassy hops with a slight spicy edge.  Short and sharp bitterness.  Alcohol is apparent.  The beer is clean, crisp and sharp but it is overall just too sweet and too harsh for the style.  It wants to be exaggeratedly cranked-up german pilsner and it probably is exactly that.  But for my thirsty palate I found my little 22oz bomber a bit long to drink.  Basically I think that a 9.5% german pilsner makes as much sense as an Individualists Union.
Pours a nice blonde golden color with a thick creamy head. Taste crisp with a hop,  floral, and citrus taste.

Bottle (bomber) from the Crcked Kettle. Clear deep golden, almost no head. Honeyish and suspiciously old/cellared aroma with some sugary madeira/raisin notes. Vague herbal and grassy hops. Medium bodied, almost flat.  a bit sweet with a nice firm bitterness. Probably a bit too old, would like to try this fresher. The biterness saves the day here.

Orange colour and hazy. Sparkling. White head, mostly lasting. Aroma is hoppy, light spicy and herbal. Complex flavor, sweet, soft, sprakling, mild, sharp bitter, dry. Notes of vanilla? Dry, dry texture.
old hoppy,amber, hazy, white foam, light sweetness, medium bitterness, medium body, creamy, bitter, long nice hoppy finish.

Enjoyed on 3/17/11 in a Pilsen glass. Egg yellow color. Foggy almost opaque body. Headed with a very dense, close & lasting foam. Thick layer, yellowish center & lemon yellow circle. Subtle malty but intense hoppy aroma, kind perfumed. Heavy & dry bitterness all over - feel the chains of a Panzer tank rolling on your tongue. The aftertaste keeps the dry bitterness but refreshing flavor. Excellent drinkability no matter alcohol level.

Very high & dense, just-yellow head over golden, well-carbonated beer with an orangeish sheen. Sweetish but with an edge - hoppy, but not at all US-hops. Bit of ureum and toasted grains coming then. Malty, even corn, but with again toasted (especially in the finish) and EU hops; bitterish finish, if the main body is sweet. Grapes retronasal. Well-carbonated, but the finish has some astringency, if mildly so. Infinitely better than the usual malt liquor. Just the effort to make something worthwile from the given, deserves an extra point.

From the Jug at the GABF, Colorado Convention Center Denver 17/09/2010
Floral hop aroma. Clear golden coloured hoppy and citrus flavoured with a hint of dryness in a bitter malt finish.

Hazy, straw colour. Big aroma of hops and some lovely sweet malt too. A very rich malty mouthfeel with again plenty of hop character too. A more robust version of a German Pils? Yes, it definately is.

Slightly cloudy straw brown with overly large head.  Aroma more malty than anything.  Meduyn body, not too much alcohol.  Flavor is mostly hoppy, some malt, a little grassy.  Some interesting components maybe doesnt all quite come together but good nonetheless.
22oz bottle. Pours yellow, solid carbonation, pillowy white head. Light hop aroma. Taste of  malt, solid finish. Hides the alcohol well.

Aroma reveals pilsener malt and saaz hops.  Pours a golden yellow with a very active carbonation.  taste is initially hyper-malty with a strong alcohol flavor typical of Imperial Pilsners.  It quickly turns bitter with a bite of hops which I surmise must be caused by the Tettnang Hops since all Saaz hops versions are more mellow in the hop area.

Bottle. Golden, hazy, small and fully diminishing head.  Moderate malty and sweetish aroma, fruity, citrus grapefruit hoppyness, some alcohol. Body is medium, malty and sweetish flavor, grapefruit hoppyness, alcohol. Finish is average, malty and sweetish, quite a lot of alcohol and not so much hoppyness, aroma - flavor not in balance.

I liked this more than I thought I would. Malt and hops -- even likable Saaz -- in good balance without funk, esters, even alcohol, or much else getting in the way. Too huge to have more than small glass and so some residual sugar was not too disturbing.

Golden yellow color with thick white foams that lasts forever. Hefeweizen lemony yeasty and hoppy aroma. Some orange, lemongrass and a strong by subtle hopiness to counter the noticeable kick at the end.

Wow - 22oz, pours gold with a hint of orange.  Minimal head, but long lasting.  Classic pilsner flavor, but with a stronger hint of hops, honey, and some spiciness that I cant quite make out. Definitely packs a wallop... great brew.

Bomber pours golden/straw with  hazy and a thin white head. Aroma is sweet grains, grass, pepper, hops, slight booze. Taste is similar to aroma very well rounded and empathizing the Tettnag hops and Saaz hop flavors.

Bottle ; Pour is a slightly cloudy gold with a nice frothy white head. Retains well - decent lacing in this shaker. Like youd expect from a decent Pils. Floral Hop nose with a splash of honey. It tastes like a pils but the mouthfeel is just heavier. No surprise. This brew worked for me - Biscuits, Floral notes, honey, and there is a bitterness present as well as a general sweetness. Nice, really

Poured into a pint glass.

3.5 A: Clear medium yellow color. Two fingers of frothy head with less than average retention and some lacing.

3.0 S: Not much of anything going on in the nose. Somewhat bready malts, but otherwise nothing. Id expect a pils this strong to put out more.

4.0 T: Taste is much more on par with what I was expecting. Healthy hop bitterness. Some earthy and spicy hop flavor. A little hot, which works helps rather than hinders. Somewhat grainy malts, yet bready as well. Not the greatest, but not bad either.

4.5 M: Heavier medium body. Good creaminess going on. Warms throughout, but especially on finish. Good carbonation.

3.5 D: I cant imagine having more than a bomber of this. Its too hot for that. Good, not great.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 11-09-2009 03:14:43

Clear orangey gold pour with a smallish white head. Nose was grassy hop aplenty mixed with sweet malt and citrus notes. Much more hop bitterness in the flavour than youd expect from this style, but thats a good thing in my book. Started out quite sweet and showed some decent fruity notes tangled up in there. Booze factor not particularly smothered, but I liked the balance on show. 
Very drinkable brew on the whole, and Im seldom too disappointed with an offering from these guys.
65cl, as Panzer Imperial Pilsner, new American brew Anno 2008, from De Hopduvel Gent, complex bitter brew, yet not too heavy, very balanced, hazy, rocky head, very good brew, yet expensive!
Bottle. Clear deep golden with big off-white head. Flavour is malt, aroma and bitter hops with notes of alcohol.

Slight hazy peach pour with a huge white head. The aroma holds bread and caramel notes with nectar fruits and a perfume like grassy hop profile. The flavor is massively hop oriented- the hoppiest pilesner Ive ever had- tons of orange grapefruit, perfume, grassy, and nectar fruits. The palate is light to medium bodied with fluffy carbonation and a resinous finish.

Hazy apricot pour with a gigantic fluffy white head. Aroma holds bread, caramel, spice and nectar fruit, and a perfume and floral hop character. The nose actually reminds me a bit of a Belgian style brew, like a saison or tripel. Flavor is incredibly hoppy, with lots of white grapefruit, lemon, and orange peel. Also grassy and flowery presence. Palate is light and drinkable, with fairly high effervescence. Pretty damn tasty!

On tap at The Daily Pint. Bright orange yellow with a slight haze, generous two-finger head that retained very well and left a nice lace. Strong floral hops character on the nose with ample biscuity malt as well. Rich Sweet bready malts up front with a strong bitter hops right behind it. Tasted like a delicious hard citrus candy. Full creamy soft mouthfeel was the highlight - the libatious equivalent of running on a pillow. Lively carbonation and a tart finish. Terrific.

clear gold, thin white head, some lace.  nose is grainy.  flavor is grainy, trace of corn, with a hop presence.  nice bitter finish, but the mouthfeel is watery.  perhaps my sample has gone flat.  i expected more of an imperial pils.
Sampled in a bomber. Pours yellow and a bit cloudy. Really full body on it. Surprised at the high alcohol content on it but you really cant taste it, its smooth and nice. Great brew.

Bottle split with Streets and pat, thanks Streets - you made the night magical. Pours a bright hazy, glowing  yellow gold body with nice white head. Aroma is fresh hops. Mouthfeel is medium and has a nice carbonated feel. Notes of fresh pine hop, some citrus. Great for a German pils.
A great Pilsener. Nice aroma and a nice complex taste. Very full flavor and body for a pilsener. I love it.

Bottle. 25. 4 oz. Split with James and Streets. Pours a soft hay yellow with a massive, soft, bubbly white head. Aroma of grapefruit, oranges, lemon zest, tangerines, some light wheat, and a healthy amount of dry, fresh hops. Medium to fuller bodied with a well rounded, roomy mouthfeel. Finishes with a nice bitter/tart combonation on the back of the tongue. Very good pilsner.

A: snifter. pours an opaque dark rich orange. light orange/khaki colored head. good retention rate. wonderful lacing.

S: deep malt aroma, citrus and strong alcohol esters. big citrus hop aromas, mostly oranges.

T: some big orange flavors from both the malts and the hops. wonderful hop flavors, some pine as well as the citrus.

M: surprisingly smooth for the ABV. smooth carbonation, very mellow.

D: ABV was a lot to read, but it is very mellow. Slow creeper, beware. very nice, best ESL I have had.

From Ølbutikken, Copenhagen, DK.
Bottled, 270710.
Golden with white head. Aroma of malt and alcohol. Flavor with hop spices and much sweetness.

Overall, this beer was terrible, it was about as vile a beer as they come. Ill avoid it like the plague form now on. 
Dumped it out in the sink, had the first bottling when released, it tasted like a mix of jizz and soap.
Bottle. Pours a pale yellow color with a small white head. Has a sweetish malty hoppy aroma. Sweetish malty grainy hoppy grassy flavor. Has a sweetish malty hoppy bitter finish.

This is a stronger type of beer and definitely hoppier than the others in the brand that Ive tried. Its pretty mellow for an imperial pils so just think Sam Adams but a little lighter. That doesnt take anything away from the brew though. Yea its a hoppy beer but its kinda floral. You can kinda taste a hint of citrus but it isnt too discernible though the the rest of the brew. For a beer thats 9.5% abv you dont really taste the alcohol much.

22 oz bottle. For such a big beer, this is quite straightforward and simple. Not too unlike a lighter vodka with a little extra fruit and bitterness mixed in. None of that is in a bad way though, as the simple character works well in this sipping beer. The aroma is clean, though slightly boozy. Notes of herb, grass, light bread, mixed heavy grapefruit, peach, and other mixed citrus fruits. Very light, bubbling head on the pour. The body of the beer looks a good deal like a concentrated orange-pineapple fruit juice. Theres a cutting crispness in the body that gives way to slightly sticky hop finish. The flavor notes again are simple, but of high quality. Herbs and more herbs, grass, potato, and mixed citrus. Overall, this was an enjoyable beer. Im undecided about this style in general, but will definitely give similar beers a go around.

My Bottom Line:
Crisp straw is emboldened by a friendly herbal hop intensity until this noble hop spiciness takes over for a bitter and lightly alcoholic finish.

Further Personal Perceptions:
-A sheet of foam sticks to the top of the hazy blond. 
-The mouthfeel is not too heavy, making this Imperial Pilsener quite easy to drink even though it is 9% abv.
-The prickly effervescence also helps this drinkability. 
-The overall flavour profile is balanced and just intense enough for what you expect from this type of brew. 
-The spicy, herbal hop bitterness benefits from the well-dried out second half.

On tap at the brewery.
Bottle from Bierkoning. Murky grapefruit body with medium head. Nice grapefruit and orange nose. Taste of fruits and spices. Tangy flavour with lots of bitter in the finish. Very enjoyable.

Slightly hazy golden pour with a white soapy bubble head, short retention receding almost completely.  Aroma is sweet grain backed up by herbal hops.  Very deceiving on the palate, seems nowhere near 9.5%, alcohol is well hidden, beer has some balance to it.  Pretty good.

Aroma - lots of grassy goodness in the aroma, a fair bit of honeyish malts

Appearance - crystal clear, golden body, 2" white head, nice retention

Taste - this is where I really enjoyed the beer.  Bready was the thought that first jumped out at me.  Bready, peppery, lots of floral hops...really enjoyed the spicy/peppery angle.  Alcohol was well hidden.

Overall - another fine brew from Port.  Its always a pleasure to get the chance to pop one of their beers open.

22 oz. bottle via trade with fidelis83- thanks again, Jeremiah!  Pours a cloudy gold with a small off-white head.  Aroma of caramel malts, orange citrus, Saaz hops, honey, dust, and candi sugar.  Flavor of caramel malts, orange citrus, honey, herbal and floral hops, and alcohol.  Bitter finish.  Light-medium bodied, with gentle carbonation and a malty mouthfeel.  Pretty good.

Silly label.  Dark gold pour, with a light head.  Very interesting aroma - honey, citrus, caramel, vanilla, fresh sweet bread.  Really nice and complex flavor.  Starts out sweet, then turns hoppy and bready - lemon muffins?  Pretty light taste for such a hi ABV brew.  I can only think of one other imperial pils I have had (Samuel Adams), and this is mellower.  It is not overly hopped, like one might expect from an imperial pilsner.  It is more like a strong, sweet pils.  RB calls it a European strong lager.  How about a new category for imperial pilsners?  With brews this good out there, it will happen eventually.

Bottle, bought @ Ølbutikken, Cph.
Pours hazy yellow, almost nu head. Aroma is citric, has lots of peachy hops and fair malty sweetness on top of a vinious edge. Lowish carbonation, fat creamy and very dry mouthfeel. Flavour is super bitter, dry, fruity, piney. Long, lingering bitterness. Just too much for me overall.

Hey, a beer that calls itself an imperial pils that  actually has discernible noble hop character! Clear golden yellow, poured by my server w/ a small head of white bubbles. Grassy hops in the nose and earthy bitterness. Medium bodied, soft carbonation and a clean malt taste. Grows slightly floral and boozy as it warms. While this is hop-centric, so is a Pilsener and most beers claiming this style are basically IIPAs made w/ lager yeast.

Flaske: Flot gul øl med et fint skumhoved. Samme problem som Christoffel Nobel der blev drukket umiddelbart før. Humlen er faded. Men ville virkelig være en glorious øl frisk. Konen var især tilfreds med at den kraftige humle ikke havde noget kattepis over sig som hun ellers er meget følsom overfor. Fantastisk når Messi så scorer endnu engang. Dejlig aften.
from a bomber,golden, hazy, 1/4 inch of head,this one great pils,strongly recommend for anyone.
Pours yellow with a white head. Aroma is malt, citrus hop, fruity notes, light butterscotch. Flavour is malt, hoppy citrus and grapefruit, light alcohol.

Bottle shared at Tims 
Appearance: Yellow straw with a small white head and lacing 
Aroma: Lemon, citrus 
Taste: Sweet malts, lemon peal and citrus 
Nice beer.

Bottle 22.fl.oz. @ home.Clear medium orange color with a small, frothy - fizzy, fair lacing, mostly diminishing, white head. Aroma is moderate malty, toasted, caramel, moderate to heavy hoppy, soap citrus, grapefruit, soap orange, grass notes. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and bitter with a average to long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20100208]

22oz bottle.  Small white head atop hazy apple juice body with some yeasty flecks.  Aroma is medium sweet, spicy, orange, light bread.  Taste is moderately sweet, orange/lemon, spicy/grass, light alcohol.  Medium-full body, some stickiness, alcohol fairly well contained.
not a huge pilsner fan, but this is a nice interpretation.  light crisp hoppy without being ale-ish.  Good maltiness up front and good hop concentration on the finish.  Stays true to the format.
Pours orange-gold with a thin lacy head. Aroma-pilsner malt, orange, hops. Taste-sweet tarts, bitter hops, citrus, earthy, grainy.  Finishes bitter and mildly citrusy and malty.

Slightly hazy yellow colour, small white head. Aroma is rather grassy and hoppy with some slight malts and mild nuttyness as well. Flavour is quite much the same. Not all too balanced.

Bottle from BOLTZ7555.  Thanks Jason!  Gold color and pours with a nice thick fluffy head.  Excellent lacing after each sip.  Bready in the aroma with grains, corn and herbs.  Surprisingly not an amped up aroma.  Very sweet and malty tasting.  Corn, bread, sticky honey, grain, bitter hops.  Ok, no hiding the Imperial part of this here.  A sharp alcohol sting that is really distracting.  A bit sour too.  Shows every bit of 9.5% and then some.  Meh.  Once upon a time I liked the idea of an Imperial Pilsner and since this seems like a pretty good representation of one I guess I dont anymore.  It just doesnt have the crisp and refreshing qualities I love from a good Pils.  I guess sometimes less is better.  I will say that this grew on me a bit after I wrote these comments.  Of course that could have been the alcohol warming me up.

Hazy pale blonde beer topped by a lasting white foam that recedes to cover. Clean and soft aroma where the alcohol remains mostly subtle. Instead, minerally grassiness and grainy malts are offering a balanced, albeit subtle performance. In mouth, I was initially quite impressed by its alcohol masking capacities, but as it warmed up, its 9.5% outgrew it and became annoying to me. Still, for an imperial pils, this does a gracious job of providing rich pils malt flavours and conveys an almost bright hoppiness of the most noble kind: floral, grassy, gently spicy. Densely carbonated medium body. While still sweeter than Id like, it possesses a more than fair dryness as opposed to more impy pilsners and its appropriate hopping enhances that feeling. All in all, a successful offering and yet another good lager from these guys, but as some of their others, their schwarzbier for instance, its ale-ish.

Bottled 660 ml at Beer Hunters
Slightly hazy golden color, small white head. Slightly hoppy and malty, slightly perfumic. Sweet malty, raw hoppy pilsner. Warming alcohol in the background. Finish has some fruity notes. More ESL than strong pils. Probably better when served fresh on tap. Now not really exciting, especially price/qualitywise.

Bottle from ØlbutikkenHazy golden color, small head. The aroma is mild, green, with some hop, vegetables, lemon peel, creamy; reasonable. The body is lean, it doesnt show the high gravity, but some alcohol warmth maybe does; quite good toffee flavor, dry, with strong bitterness, but the hop doesnt have enough qualities, its just a bit resiny; the final, hop-toffee, is pleasant. Flawless.Overall, its an enjoyable beer, much better than a common Strong Lager, but with a more aromatic hop (and fruity) the result could have been of another league.

Bomber. Great yellow and orange interesting color with ultra thin white head. Aroma is citrus lemon but boozy... Flavor is lemon-grass hoppy and very boozy. Clean mouthful. A great brew Ill go back to again.

Tasty. Does a good job of balancing the clean malt and hops only flavor with the high alcohol, although the alcohol does come through a bit too much. Nice balance of sweet and dry, more towards dry. Lemony and grassy, very light in color, pretty bitter.
I love hoppy lagers and this is one of them. floral aroma, light clean and crisp with a lot of flavor.

A: The beer pours a hazy light golden/orange color with a finger or so of white foam. There are also spots of lacing.

S: There are a lot of citrus hop aromas, primarily orange and lemon. There is also a bit of a sweet, sugary smell.

T: The taste was quite a let down. Initially, it is good, lots of orange flavors from the hops. The finish and aftertaste are quite another story. There is an overly bitter and extremely alcoholic flavor, along with quite a bit of alcoholic heat.

M: The carbonation is moderate, I feel it should be a bit higher for a Pilsner. The body is also quite heavy for a Pilsner, but I can deal with that.

D: The aftertaste and alcoholic burn detract from the drinkability of this beer in a big way. I was expecting more from Pizza Port, this beer was definitely a disappointment.
Bottle. Pours a golden beer with a weak white/offwhite head. The aroma is fruit, hops and malt. The flavor is sweetness, malt and some spices. The palate is dry and bitter. Overall a good beer.

Hazy body with thin creamy head.  Aroma is remarkably doughy.  It smells like a real pilsner as opposed to the über hopped imperial pils Im used to encountering.  Really nice flavor thats a little sweet and citrusy, but with that malty doughy backbone.  Nice creamy mouthfeel.  Finishes really nicely.  Good beer.

On tap at the Bierstube in Moline Iowa. Pours dark gold with a medium white head. Thick, very thick, honeysuckle aroma. This aint your Fraus pils. Its sweet in a candy way. But that sweetness is quickly eradicated by the intense hops. This has a long, bitter finish. A monster bier.

22 oz. bottle from weeheavySD.  Pours a hazy golden orange color with a medium white head.  The nose is fruity (peaches) with a sticky moderately sweet maltiness.  The flavor is heavily fruity and sweet malts combining for one big beer.  There are more hops associated with the flavor; mostly earthy which adds to a dry bitterness in the finish.  Medium-full bodied, thick and sticky.  This is a pilsner in name only.
Bottle. Nice head with good duration. Color is golden. Aroma and taste are hops, malt, grass and some alcohol.
Bottled. A hazy golden beer with a thin off-white head. The aroma has notes of malt and citrusy hops. The flavor is sweet with notes of malt and spices. Thanks yespr for sharing.

22 fl oz bottle. Pours hazy orange with a small white head. Aroma is dry peachy and fruity. tangering and crisp hops fruity flavoured. Dry and bitter. Distinct citrusy note. Sweet and tangerine finish. Bitter and dry. Nice one.

Bottle 65 cl. Courtesy of yespr. Pours golden with a slight haze and a tiny off-white head. Aroma is sweet malty with some citrusy hops. Medium body, again sweet malts, slightly biscuity and a massive bitterness. 080210
Bottle pour.Gold color with a great white head.Nose was very floral with grass,citrus,and citrus hints.Taste was hops,with a little citrus and sweet malt.Very drinkable.

Thanks kiefdog for the share.  Pours hazy yellow with a frothy, off-white head.  Nose is lemon, bread, citrus hops, booze, and floral hops.  Flavor is similar with a nice floral hoppy bite.  Medium-bodied and almost no lager taste to it.

A bitter and flavorful West Coast hop-head interpretation of the Pilsner style. A 22 oz bottle from BevMo with memories of a tapped 1/2 growler from Malt & Vine. Slightly cloudy lemon yellow pour has lasting but thin white head and lacing a-plenty. Faint aromas of citrus, freshly cut wheatgrass, vanilla bean, and honeydew mellon. Flavor is strong and fresh of hops, hops, and more hops. Followed by chewy bread dough and lemonheads candy aftertaste. Abundant bitterness glides above all the effervescent light malt. Alcohol is fiendishly well hidden till you get 3/4 of the way through the bottle. Finish is dry and tingly, but with a mouth reaction like a coating of refrigerated marijuana butter.

Bottled. Golden coloured. Unclear. Dense off white head. Aroma of fruits, grass, bread, spice, some flowers and light grape. Flavour of light caramel, spice, grass, citrus, flowers and alcohol. Medium bodied. Dry grassy and somewhat citric bitterness in the end. Alcoholwarming especially on the palate. Not really my kind of beer.

(Bottle at Pikkulintu) Poured golden and almost clear with medium sized and white head. Aroma contained grass, hops and alcohol, Palate was medium bodied with medium carbonation. Flavours were malts, alcohol, hops, grass, sweetness, fruitiness and bitterness. Aftertaste contained alcohol and bitterness.

Botella. Cloudy unfiltered orange juice colour, medium fairly well lasting white head. Fruitish yeasty aroma. Good mouthfeel. Flavour, fruits, sweet, hops,  citrus, pleasant bitterness. dry bitter fruity finish.

Bottle. Low but lasting white fluffy head. Hazy dark yellow body. Somewhat muddy straw barley malt aroma, hops strangely subdued. Hops bitterness though heavily and well represented in the flavor which is rather dry as well as a bit sharp but not too much of a good thing. I does however have a piny note. Low carbonation, long bitter aftertaste. Would not have guessed on such a hich alcohol level.

Port Brewing Company--Panzer Imperial Pilsner--2009  Release--22 oz. Bottle--9.50% ABV--75 IBUs?  (4.75 / 5.0)  Pilsner--Imperial--Thin no lace white head.  Clear pretty yellow gold color hazes lemon with sediment.  Rich floral Saaz hop front.  Butter sweet smooth rich Pils malt mild creamy crisp refreshing deceptively big body.  Cloying crusty balanced hop spice smooth malt mild citrus end.  Sampled 10/2/2009.  $7.99 Each.

UPDATED: JAN 30, 2010 (Bottled, 0.65l) Slightly hazy golden with a smallish, bubbly head. Grassy-hoppy nose with alcohol present, but honeyish and non-intrusive. Flavor is pale-malty, somewhat alcoholic and acidic, with moderate, grassy hops. Medium body with some acidic alcohol and soft carbonation. Might be the first US beer, that actually reminds me of Estonian booze lagers.

Sweet honey and caramel flavors abound in this full bodied and yet smooth drink. Butterscotch and grassy aromas. Toasty grains and a grassy bitter finish. Getting most of this now that it has all warmed a bit so give this a sec to warm up after pulling it from the fridge.

22oz. bottle.  Sweet, fruity aroma, citric and lightly sugary, with suggestions of lemon, herbal hop and a bready, grainy malt note.  Medium golden color, hazy and heavily bottle-conditioned, with a fine, slight head.  Very nicely flavorful profile, with plenty of sweet, crackery, honeyish malt, pine, citrus and spice, and just a hint of peppery alcohol towards the finish.  Smooth and surprisingly thin on the palate for a beer of this strength, body is full.  Pleasantly strong, lingering hop tones late.  Extremely dangerous and drinkable.

pours a pale yellow with a small white head, and good lacing.

smell is of grain, corn, some citrus, and a little malt.

taste is of hops, citrus, grain, and some malt, ends a little dry.

Bottle from Todd the Wet Sprocket.Pours a rich, cohesive, inviting gold with a thick head of white.  Aroma is sublte grain, slight lemon, Sprite/7-Up, and a touch of rose.  Flavor is a doughy, sweet malt and grain with a touch of floral lemon in the finish.  Subtle hints of sweetened grass linger.  Nice, full mouthfeel.  A fine, fine pilsner with the high ABV hidden all too well.
user_location: Ugly, Hot, and Humid Spring, Texas, USA

text: Bottle from Jessup Plaza Beverage in PA.  Pours a slightly hazy gold with a thin whtie head.  Nose is a messy combinatino of clay, fruit (pineapple, blueberries), alcohol, toasted malt and a bit of pepper.  Flavor is nice enough malt, a whole bunch of up front bitterness, some green apple (or pear?) and alcohol.  The finish is the best part with herbal hop character coming out to mingle with the malt, alcohol & slight astringency.  Entier the body is too heavy or the carbonation is too light - this one is kinda syrupy.

Bottle at home.
Hazy golden coloured with a small white head.
Sweet aroma of malts, caramel, hay, hops and pine needles.
Fruity flavour of caramel, hops, pine needles and dried fruits.
Dry hoppy finish.
Well hidden alcohol.
Hazy golden with a small white head. Clean hoppy aroma with ppine, herbs and citrus. Sweetish caramel flavour with lots of pine hops. Very bitter with a toouch of alcohol

Bomber. Pours a hazy yellow to golden with one finger white head. Aroma is  sweet and floral with notes of honey, caramel, spice, yeast, light funk, floral esters. Flavor is sweet and floral with honey, caramel, grain, yeast, floral hops, cereal, light spice note. Medium body with a clean finish.

cloudy orange, strange looking (milk skinned) smooth offwhite head.
gentle flowery hops dominate. peach. flowers.yeast. nice.
flavor is pretty bitter, faint flowers, hoppy, sweet from malts, strong. ends bitter from alc and bitter hops. reminds me of a bitterhoppy imperial ipa or double ipa, benearth the bitterhoppy grapefruitpeel bitterness i find an intersting peachy orangy flowery sweetness the two doesnt match in total harmony with the powerfull bitterness, but you stop and examine it a bit.

Bottle shared by faroeviking. Cloudy orange juice like body with a medium white head. The aroma is fruity, medium hoppy and light plastic like. The flavour is oranges, hops, fruit and light caramel. Alcohol is well hiddin. Disappointing.

22oz Bomber  Gravity Beer Market  Olympia, WA
Aroma  Good malt and lots of fruit aromas along with some hops.   
Appearance  Golden yellow in color, Hazy with a light head.   
Flavor  Nice malt flavor with a good fruit like flavors I caught some grapefruit and nice hops . 
Palate    Dry finish with a nice Mouthfeel. 
Overall   For an Imperial this was weak I was hoping for it to be stronger in the flavor. Finishes quite nice this was not for the armature drinker.

Small head that reduces to a single layer of bubbles except along the edge.  Cloudy gold color.

Mild hoppy aroma--like grapefruit.  Even lighter alcohol nose.  

Dry and light in the malt.  Good hop presence without overwhelming.  The swallow and aftertaste feature a stronger bitterness.  The mouth is neutral.  The carbonation is elevated but acceptable.  The alcohol is notable, but not in an oily way.

Overall, this is a loaded brew in terms of flavor and balance.  It lives to its name of an extreme pilsner.

Draft.  Poured a translucent gold with a thin white head, leaving a little lacing.  Has a slightly grassy, hoppy aroma.  Flavor is a little toasty, clean, spicy, piney, and grassy.  Definitely a big noble hop presence.  Has an excellent finish,  very dry and warm.
Bottled 65cl. Murky yellow beer. Hop resin and honey in the nose. Balanced taste. Strong bitterness.

Pours a dark gold with nice big white head.  Nose is malty pils with some hops.  Flavor is sweet, malty with warmth of alcohol.  Oh did I mention that it has a big dry hoppy bitter finish.  Very nice, something different.

Seems to be a rather lightly carbonated brew as  rigorous pour results in just a moderate, but stable off-white head. Lightly hazed light golden color. Fresh hop aroma with a little citrus. Hints of pale malt in the background. Seems to smell more like a pale ale than a lager. Still rather pleasing. Dry flavors. Just a bit of sweetness offset by a light herbal bitterness. I dont catch the "normal" malt liquor flavors that I find in many of this styles ilk, but I do catch the hops profile I find in many a Euro Strong. Actually hides the alcohol quite well. For me this need a bit more malt character to help balance the hops bite.

22 oz. bottle from 99 Bottles. Haze orange color with no head to be seen. Nice pleasantly strong pislner aroma. A few subtle sweet aromas coming through as well. A nice strong aroma just punching me in my face (freshly shaven might I add!). Hints of hops are coming through as well. Just a fresh pilsner aroma.  Wow, thats a smooth lager. Nice sweet pale malt flavor, and then a nice bittering pislner flavor that just provides such a nice hop bite at the end. Great brew.
Bottle. Clear golden with medium white head. Hoppy aroma with citric and malty notes. Flavor of hops, some grapefruit and pine notes. Solid dry and bitter finish.

Courtesy my Secret Santa- thanks man! Great imperial pilsener. Leave it to us in the U.S. to come up with this concept. Aroma was big. All pilsner malt with not much else. Pour was a beautiful dark gold with a huge pillowy white head. Taste was strong. Strong pilsner malt with a heavy dose of European hops to balance out the sweetness. Semi-dry finish with nice carbonation. Delicious.
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Thanks Chibbyman. Yellow pour with a white head. Sweet malt aroma. The alcohol seemed to balance nicely with the malt. Some sweetness at the end. Nice lacing. Tasty.

Bottle @ Hj Hansen, Odense. Pours slightly unclear golden with a egg white head and lacings. Nose is very grassy with notes of pine and flowers. Very hoppy and very bitter grassy abd citrussy flavor. Smooth mouthfeel. Medium carbonation. Dry and power bitter long end. Heavy!

Beautiful appearance!  Pours slight hazy golden color with thick & luscious white head.  Gorgeous!

Nose has some herbal qualities, perhaps with some resemblance to skunky hops in a green glass German import.  

Palate has a clean character with some dry herbal flavors.  Finish is hoppy with some alcohol peeping through.

There really has to be a new category for all of these "Imperial Pilseners" that have been cropping up the past few years.  About all they have in common with genuine European Strong Lagers is that theyre strong pale lagers and not Malt Liquors.  Anywhat - I picked up a bomber of this beverage at the Binnys in Orland park, Illinois.  It poured a yellow body with lazy carbonation and a smallish head that left little lace.  The aroma was a grainy malt sweetness covered by some muddy PNW hop scents.  The flavor was cleaner so far as the hops were concerned, citrus zest with a dash of resinous pine.  The finish was the best part, dry and bitter.  Not bad.
Pours a gold honey with a very thin head and lots of rising bubbles.  A faint IPA-like aroma, with some yeast, barnyard and citrus.  Taste is much the same, citrus and earth with a bitter finish.

Nice aroma,  grassy/piney hops over fresh baked bread and candied tropical fruits.  Flavor starts out fruity but is pretty aggressively hoppy, at least for these hop varieties, with a pronounced bitter finish.

Pale yellow pour with out much visible crabonation, oddly.  Nose is somewhat tart.  Flavors of lightly roasted grain (almost thought I tasted some corn adjuncts) decent bittering hops (floral and earthy) and a tart finish.  Did not really grab me at all.

22 oz. bottle. Pours a tiny bubbled, white head of good duration, with extensive lacing, over a cloudy, golden (SRM 5) body.......nose is light toffee, bit of honey, slight bread, floral Herby hops....taste light malt sweetness to start finishing with  a spicy, slightly peppery hop bitterness.....mouth feel is medium to light, carbonation makes fora creamy sensation....the alcohol is well hidden. This is a very interesting beer. It is without a doubt the Pilsner style, but it is so big, heavy and nicely balanced that it could be dangerous. This is a style (European Strong Lagers)  worth investigating further.

UPDATED: MAR 9, 2010 Clear golden pour with moderate white head.  Aroma is mildly sweet ... grassy, skunky, with dank floral hop notes.  Taste is much the same ... and  the slightly more viscous mouthfeel is making this a real chore to choke down.  Hides the higher abv well.  I tried to give it as much respect as possible, wading through about half the bomber to give it a fair shake ... but had absolutely no interest in sampling it any further at that point.  Anyone who knows me at all, can attest that I am all for new and/or innovative brews; but this is just nonsense.  In my opinion, this "imperial tank" simply rolls over and destroys what is so great about a real pilsener in the first place.  Just not my thing, I guess.

Super citrusy, caramel, pears.
Taste was very hoppy but not bitter. Very crisp, sweet, and malty.
Poured a light clear golden color with nice head.
Medium carbonation.
Overall really refreshing.

Bottle: Poured a hazy golden color lager with a small foamy head with minimal retention and some light lacing. Aroma of dry European hops with some grainy malt notes. Taste is a mix between some some dry European hops with subtle floral notes and light astringency. Malt is dominated by grainy notes and doesnt really fits well with the beer. Body is full with limited filtration and carbonation is too low for style. Not my favorite style but I still think the malt and hops were not in perfect agreement and carbonation was too low for the style.

Pale golden pour nice white head  ... sweet citrus hop aroma .... a hearty bready pils taste with a wicked fruity/hop bite ..... very citrusy and spicy finish .... definitely different than the usual beers out there .... was pretty well balanced .... pretty much a pils flavor with a hop bite took getting used to .. hides the abv well
Bottle. Pours clear golden with a minimal head. Fairly hoppy flavor with grass and sour citrus aspects. Sour taste that becomes intensely bitter with the finish.

Bomber.  Poured clear golden with a short, looser-bubbled white head.  The aroma picked up toasty pale malts and honey topped by spicy white pepper, floral hoppage, and a pinch of corn.. warm overall and inviting.  The flavor found honey, corn, and lesser bready malts at the core.. heavy floral character around as well as peppery alcohol warmth.. the hops really took over and left the most memorable impression (which I enjoyed).  Medium-bodied with low carbonation on the palate.. very bitter, especially as it warmed up.. dry, warm, spicy, and enjoyable.  Id have another.
draft: pours clear amber, hoppy aroma, slightly buttery taste, mildly hoppy, bitter finish, a very nice pils...best imperial pils Ive had

UPDATED: NOV 4, 2009 22oz bomber.  Pours a clear, but somewhat viscous looking, rich golden with a thin fine dense fizzy white froth.   Interesting play of the citrus hops, piney hops and the spicy nobles, slightly biscuity malts, some sweetness and a light touch of alcohol as it warms, floral and fragrant.  First taste follows aroma, interesting and new play of citrus, pine and noble, just slightly cheesy, actually seemingly balanced between the the flavors which seems almost like it was mixed rather than brewed that way, malts are biscuity, sugary sweet but finishing dryer, fairly clean finish, very very bitter, love the bitterness, SUPER BITTER. Alcohol blends well with flavor, not noticeable unless one looks for it.  Lively sizzling carbonation that doesnt allow one to focus on the typical Port syrupy viscousness, makes it crisp but soft overall.  I have a feeling some of the biscuitiness is partly due to slight oxidation, maybe would be a bit better if the PNW hops were toned down a tad and a little less residual sugar... of course Im really just drawing comparisons to Sam Adams Imp Pils... =p  I applaud any brewer who decides to try and pull this style off... we really need more of these ultra bitter pils.

Bottle from jessup plaza. Poured a hazey yellow gold color with a small off white head that didnt last long. Aroma is light hop aromas of grapefruit and pine. Taste is fresh and strong with hops up front and a strong alcohol finish. Very dry at the end. Quite bitter.
Thanks to Josh for this!  Hazy amber pour.  Pine and grapefruit on the nose.  Biscuit malts, pine, grapefruit and a bitter dry finish.  Very resinous

22. Pours a cloudy medium toffeeish amber. Loose sudsy platinum blonde foam knocking around, with bubbly, foamy lace sheeting down the sides of the glass. Attractive but not quite a cover girl. Nice mix of pine and grapefruit on the nose, very sugary and fragrant hops. Super inviting, and very much in SD IPA territory. Creamy medium body, very tight carb, a little bit of carbonic bite. Not unpleasant at all, and understated. Biscuits, pine, and grapefruit on the mid palate. Very bitter resiny finish. Nothing newsworthy by beer geek standards, but on the high side and rather sharp with that carbonic bite under it. Long dry resiny finish with maybe a little twang creeping in on it. Surprisingly refreshing for 9.5, thats for sure, and the booze is well hidden except for that seeming twang in the finish (long after the beer leaves the mouth).

650 ml bottle

I was hoping that coming from Lost Abbey/Port Brewing this would be a nice amped up pilsener in the vein of what New Glarus released a while ago.  Instead it was a bit too much; the alcohol or something else detracts from what would otherwise be a solid pils.

Aroma / Appearance - Carbonated rose gold liquid starts promisingly.  A radiant white head glowed like the morning sun.  Crisp warm multigrain bread fresh from the oven was not quite what I expected but still good enough.  Lemon pledge gave it a hoppy background.

Flavor / Palate - Hoppy with a wheat bite the alcohol takes this one over the top.  A honeylike finish is acceptable but this could be so much more.  Overall it is drinkable and I have no major complaints for a $7.99 release.  However if you are used to Port only releasing gems temper your expectations somewhat before opening it.

Bottle in the VIP tent at WBF Durham. I was expecting a bit more from this. Golden bodied with a tall white head. Aroma is Euro hops, grass, melon, and other fruit notes. Some biscuity malts as well. Taste is herbal and grassy with more Euro hops, straw, fruit notes and more toasted, biscuity malts. Body is medium-full with a softer prickly carbonation. Ends with more grass, Euro hops, herbal notes, lemon, and biscuity malts. Not bad but this was a bit of a disappointment for our group. We jumped all over this when we saw it and had our hearts a bit broken since we love Pizza Port/Lost Abbey. I would love to try this again since theres a chance this could have been an off bottle.

Aroma of candied grapefruit, ripe banana and tart cherry. Appearance was rich and gold with foamy head, nice lacing. Flavor of gum, bitter grapefruit, tart cherry and white grape. Palate was lively. An artistic brew.

22 oz bottle purchased mail order from South Bay in Imperial Beach, California. Pour is hazed yellow with a one inch white head. Some lacing etched on the glass as the head and beer fall. Aroma of grassy hops, soft minty maltiness, and some alcohol . Taste is dirty chemical sweetness (others said DMS) and the mintiness from the nose. Hops come through clean - very drying. Palate is medium to thin, medium carbonation level and a very dry finish. Nice enough, I liked the hops, though the menthol was a bit much for me. As always, thanks for doing mail order Geoi.

Yellow pour with a frothy white head.  aroma is quite nice, some nectar fruit, peaches and pears and some grassy hop character.  Flavor reveals some pepper spice as well and a nice grassy hoppiness. Interesting and pretty good take on the style

Bottle from Friar Tuck in Savoy IL, Pours golden amber with a dissipating white head. Aroma of pilsner malts, honey, and lager esters. Medium bodied with a clean mouthfeel, and not sticky like some examples. Malt backbone is of biscuit, countered by a very assertive grassy and herbal European hop bitterness. Notes of lemon in there as well. Finish is peppery and warming, and you definitely feel the alcohol. Not bad. If you want a beer with balls, but do not want the heavier body and mouthfeel, this is perfect.

Bottle pours gold with a soapy white head.  Aroma is suprisingly nice, pilsners tend to lack in this department for me.  Scents of peach, melon, lemongrass, and bubblegum. Doesnt quite translate over in the flavor side though.  Slightly doughy with a little bit of lemon and a touch of alcohol.  Suprisingly full mouthfeel for a pils, yet not quite redeeming.  I guess the nose got me excited and ill have to give this one another try.
Draft @ hulmevillle inn. Golden pour with some white head. Nice sweet aroma of fruits and wheat. Flavor however doesnt cover the high alcohol at all. Eh.

650 mL. Pours a cloudy light yellow with a very small white head. Spots of lacing. Aroma is fruity with rich cantaloupe, apricots, pineapple, but also some grass and lemon. Taste is very alcoholic- a huge gin note dominates with a juniper berry/pine needle bite. Wow- Im not sure what I think of this. It does not remind me of a pils whatsoever. It has a spicy hop bite and the bittering hops are spicy/piney, but the mouthfeel is juicy rather than dry. The mouthfeel is creamy rather than watery and clean. It is good and yummy, but Im not sure what Tomme is getting at.

Bright amber with a thin head. Quiet grassy aroma. BIG alcohol dominance start to finish. Despite the alcohol after the first sip you are intrigued and want more. A gentle pilsener under the alcohol kepps trying to rise up. The alcohol seems to think that it owns this beer and it is like some scientists creation as the alcohol takes over the pilsener and becomes something more. Not a great delicate crisp pilsener but an intriguing new creation.

22oz. bomber bottle. Slightly hazy yellow color. Minimal head and little to no lace. The aroma is dry and hoppy, with nothing really special standing out about it. The hops kind of pile on top of the flavor--theres some citrus and some pine. However, theres very little underneath the hops. The finish in particular vanishes rather quickly. Theres an interesting hop profile here waiting for something a little more substantial to carry it. The alcohol does hide pretty well in the mix.

aroma is of flowery hops taken to the wild extreme so they are no longer perfumed but intensely bittered.  appearance is honey yellow with very low carb. flavor is of intense bitterness with big alcohol bite. ultra bitter/sour end like eating an asprin. this cant possibly hold a candle to krampus.

Clear straw yellow color with next to no white head.  Aroma of hops, bread, and some citrus. Smooth and creamy with a citrus, hops taste with just a little bread.  Very slight alcohol bite.  Not a true pilsner at all.  Definitely a hybrid of a few things.

Hazy orange pour with minimal head. Bright, hoppy aroma.  Light citrus and bread.  Very strong alcohol and hoppy flavor with bready malt.  Finished with grapefruit rinds and alcohol.  Mouthfeel doesnt get syrupy, which is appreciated.  Pretty cool beer.

Hazy gold with big, foamy white head / Nose of yeasty bread, lemon, and violets / Medium body, somewhat sweet, creamy with good malts balancing potent hops, and with smooth, slightly hot, finish / Flavors of orange, lemon, apple, bubblegum, violets, chrysanthemum, honey, and hops / Pilsner character dwarfed by the big, hoppy, ale-like character of this stunner.

On tap at the Belgian Cafe

Pours a hazy cloudy bright golden yellow with a one finger frothy white head that quickly settles into a lasting ring, leaving sporadic patches of soapy lacing.

Aroma is very hoppy, especially for the style with a very strong alcohol presence as well as bready yeast, pilsner malt and some earthy grass/straw notes.

This beer is very hop forward and lingers into a bready yeasty body with a decent pilsner malt backbone. Slight earthy grass notes are followed by a very astringent strong alcohol finish. I dont really know how you could call this a pilsner. It seems like they pitched some pilsner malt into some kind of hoppy alcohol juice. Way too hoppy and too much of an alcohol presence. The body is full with some of the above mentioned bready yeast but the ABV is not masked at all. This beer is kind of a sloppy mess. They just hopped up some ingredients and slapped the word imperial on there. Avoid this one.

Poiured a cloudy golden color with an ample white head and good lacing.  The aroma was some sweet, bready malts and plenty of dry pine hops.  The flavor was slightly sweet with some grass and a relentless bitter aspirin flavor on the finish that I found very distracting.  The mouthfeel was above average.  Overall it was a bit of a mess.

UPDATED: DEC 28, 2009 Like Mikkeller Draft Bear, its hard to pretend that anything thats hazy and hopped to hell and back with American hops has anything to do with Pils.  Tasty though, even if  I have to dock it a point overall for completely violating the style.  Cloudy rich yellow, white head, moderate lacing; great appearance.  Nose of sweet malts and  a wonderful excess of hops.  Taste of sweet malts and enormous bitter hoppiness, in perfect balance.  I love this, but I cannot really call it an imperial pils.  I dont really care, its great, but its not a pils. // After retasting the beer, and some pretty strong reprimands from other ratebeer raters, i need to modify my review.  The beer does not have American hops.  It is still hopped to hell and back, but it does still try to follow the rules for a pils, sort of like the Imperial from Sam Adams.  Its brutally strong, sort of a Czech Double IPA.

Pours bright gold into a shaker.  Bright white head with medium retention recedes to skim surface. Sweet caramel malt aromas. Thick with upfront caramel and resin.  Lasting grapefruit and alcohol finish.

Bottle. Pours a slightly cloudy brilliant yellow color with a short lived yet lacy head development. Aroma is a mix of light fruits such as apricot, lemon, and a touch of grapefruit. Some stale hops in there as well, with a sweet candy sugar and coriander note hanging above the malt. Flavor follows the sweet sugary character of the aroma, with a good bitter hop punch on the back end. Alcohol becomes increasingly noticeable at the end of each sip. Medium to thin body, modest complexity. Interesting.

Draft TJs - bright golden pour thin white head.  Aroma is earthy musty and hoppy.  Mouthfeel is soft and sweet.  Flavor is divided between deep sweetness and chewy hoppiness.  A bit out of whack but decent.
Hazy straw body with minimal white head.  Grainy malt character that is syrupy sweet .  Floral hops with citrus and pepper.  Grassy with notable pine presence.  One hopped up pilsener.
22 oz bomber.  Pours a clear orange yellow gold with a small white head.  Aroma of crisp hops, candied malt and light citrus.  Taste of candied malt, sweet grapefruit, and bread dough.  Nice.

Bottle from Craft.  Pours turbid gold with 1-finger white head.  Nose is Saaz hops, citrus, malt.  Tastes fruity, hoppy, crisp, Saazy, with a fairly rich palate and some mild late heat.  Decent complexity in this, and a definite repeater for me.

Bottle  Pours a hazy golden straw color with a thin dirty white head.  The head fades quickly.  For lack of head laces very well.  Aroma is a good mix of hops and malts.  Has a sweet bread to it.  Has a good carbonation.  The flavor is good.  Alcohol is evident.  Has a good balance.  The texture is oily.  Has a medium body.  A slight alcohol burn which is good.  The finish is great with a awesome aftertaste.

Draft at red bones. Pours a dark orange color with a small off white head. Nose is pretty hoppy with some nice grassy and toast notes to it. Palate is full as is the style from Port Brewing. Flavor is hops with some biscuity maltiness and a clean finish.

22oz. Bottle.  Pours a deep golden straw color with virtually no head.  Clean, crisp aroma with a touch of bread dough and spice that has pils written all over it. Has a big Pilsner flavor with lots of malt, some toasted character, spicy pepper and a light cereal taste.  Hops are present, but the bitterness is relatively mild and lends a dryness to the beer.  Definitely shows more sweetness in the flavor and the finish is dry.  I actually felt the booze was pretty well disguised factoring in the style and the alcohol content.

Bottle.

Head is initially small, fizzy, white, mostly diminishing.
Body is medium yellow.

Aroma is lightly malty (toasted grain), moderately hoppy (resin), with light notes of gum, pineapple, pepper.

Flavor is moderately to heavily sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, lightly to moderately bitter.
Finish is lightly to moderately sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, moderately bitter.

Medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation, moderately to heavily alcoholic.

Mostly a green hop bomb in the nose, but there are some subtleties there too (which all admittedly smells much more like a strong ale than a strong pils).  A bit on the sweet side, and overly boozy, but the balance is better than one might expect...its not particularly fatiguing.

Huge malt but there are plenty of hops even on the nose.  Flavor is very malty, but not overly sweet.  Very well balanced with a nice hop presence in the finish.  Very refreshing, and very full-bodied.
22 oz bottle from Julios.  Overall, an OK beer, but the alcohol is quite evident.  I wouldnt pick it up again.

22 oz bottle from SouthBay. Pours a nice mellow golden pour with some lighter haze, a small bright white head that dies to a film and clings to the corners. Aromas are a nice crisp pilsner malt, some noble hoppiness that brings on a slight dryness, light white wine character lacking the sweetness. A good body, a bit boozy and warm, good hoppy bitterness that is dry, a touch of sauvignon grape, grainy malts with light cereal. A bit warm and bitter for my liking, with flowers and a touch of soap, but then again I dont like the Imperial Pilsner style. Ok.
grapefruit and orange hops, id say pretty moderate on malts, poured small white head... good but nothing too serious.

UPDATED: NOV 11, 2010 11/11/2010:  22oz. Bottle:  Aroma of Noble hops, light Pils malts, and some grain.  Poured yellow/gold/slight amber in color with a small, loose, off-white head that lasted throughout.  Cloudy.  Sparkling.  Full of small and medium-sized particles throughout.  Flavor is lightly sweet and medium to heavily bitter.  Tastes of Pils malts, Saaz hops, noble hops, and some grain.  Medium body.  Tingly, then dry texture.  Average to lively carbonation.  Pils malt, Noble hops, Saaz hops finish is dry.  9.5%ABV is completely hidden throughout.  


9/11/2009:  Draught at TND:  Aroma of noble hops, citrus, light Pils malts, and light fruit.  Poured yellow/gold in color with a small, loose, white head that lasted throughout.  Hazy.  Very sparkling.  Good to very good lacing.  Flavor is medium to heavily bitter.  Tastes of noble hops, Pils malts, and a hint of grass.  Medium body.  Lightly tingly, lightly dry texture.  Average to lively carbonation.  Noble hop and Pils malt finish is quite bitter.  9.5%ABV is totally hidden.  8/4/8/4/14=3.8

22 oz bottle via lagunitasfan (big thanks!). Pours a semi hazy amber with an average white head. Nose is mostly alcoholic and grains. Taste is grainy, spicy, peppercorns, with some citrus/spicy hops. Body is medium, carbonation is medium. Astringent finish. A bit hot.

Bottle.  Pours gold with a disappointingly small head.  Nose had a blast of fresh herbal hops initially, then some residual sugar, alcohol and grain.  Flavor is a bit muddy, with a blend of herbal hops, medium sugar sweetness, plastic and alcohol.  I just cant get into this one.  The alcohol on the finish is noticeable, and the body has a thickness that ruins the pilsner reference.  Overall, I suppose this is a decent offering, but it seems overdone and unbalanced, with flavors that clash along the palate until a boozy finish.

Bottle. Pours a clear golden color with a large fluffy white head. Aroma is bready and maybe a little herbal. Flavor is mostly sweet, with pepper and herbal medicinal qualities. Finish is a bit warm and sticky. I took horrible notes on this one, that may indicate it was better than I thought.

Pours a pale gold with a thin, chunky white head that fades to a ring after a pretty short period of time, but holds and leaves a few specs of lacing. Aroma is lemongrass, stale white bread, sweet citrus, salty pastry dough, a bright tangy chili note - habanero maybe?, herbal and toasted grain notes . A little ethanol and mineral come out as it warms. Flavor is spicy grass, floral, sweet and cereal grain, a little toasted grain, limestone, a hint of orange marmalade, sweet floral notes, a berry like sweetness, a little palate smacking brings out some fruity, berry notes, theres some ethanol and grapefruit near the finish. More cereal and sweet grain notes come out as it warms. Finishes off with light grapefruit, spicy grass, bitter and herbal hops, dandelion green and some mineral and medicinal notes to the fade, the medicinal notes are not too bad and get better as it warms, and appear to continue getting better as it approaches room temperature, but the beer gets pretty hot and sweet by that point. Palate is medium body with a creamy/oily feel and moderate carbonation. Really strange brew with a lot going for it, unfortunately it has a few off notes against it as well. It seems to keep alot of Pilsner like flavors and aromas in its imperial quest but loses much of the subtlety of a good pils with the hot ethanol and odd bitter/medicinal/dandelion notes. All of that being said, I still enjoyed this brew, quite a few quibbles for a decent score I guess. Pouring the dreggs in toward the end of the bottle doesnt help, but doesnt make it much worse.

Pour is a sparkling clear, straw-gold color with an average, brilliant white, pillowy head which is somewhat lasting and leaves some sporadic lace.  Nose is very faint for a 9.5% beer; notes of cookie, tangerine, floral, white pepper, and faint biscuity notes.  Flavor is similar with not much intensity; light honey and faint cookie make up the malt notes, some dusty yeast, and hops which are lemon zest, floral, lightly herbal, and lightly spicy.  Palate is lightly warm, crisp, medium, lively, and somewhat round; interesting to be round and crisp.  Finishes a bit offputting with some alcohol, light floral, and lingering notes of pepper and herbal hops.  It was weird to have a beer with a less than moderate bitterness but so much pepper and herbal hop notes, not really something that I enjoyed.  A style that seems to be very inconsistent ranging from very light, crisp strong lager-type beers, to full, very complex beers, almost ale-like due to the high OG, and this one seemed to fit somewhere on the lighter side with a more full body.  I think what is really throwing me is the fact that this one is very table-strength-pils-like and I am not a big fan of that style; usually the ESLs tend to carry more ale characteristics and more bitterness, which I like.  One of my favorite breweries but not one of favorites from them.  If you like pilsners, this one is literally just a stronger version.

courtesy of tpd975. Shared at a pool right by the Gulf of Mexico. Cheers to that!

bottle.  light haze, straw pour with thin frothy lasting white head.  light bready aroma with lemon and corn.  up front bitterness.  funky, corn, hoppy.  strange lingering sweetness.  big.

Appearance:  Pours a cloudy dull pastel yellow with a pin stripe of white foam at the top.

Aroma:  Lemon zest and dry bready malt.

Taste:  Light honeysuckle and lemon drop sweetness, finishing with a bold spicy bitter hop.

Mouthfeel: Thick and full bodied. Not sticky nor syrupy.

Overall:  Wow. Ive been scared to try a beer close to this style. I did not like Samuel Adams Imperial Pilsner, and Im not a huge fan of classic pilsner.  This beer is fucking magnificent.  Bold yet balanced.
Served cold from bottle. Faint aroma of pilsner malts and bread notes. Sweet, slightly metallic, sort of IPA-ish. Not overly impressive, but not bad either.

Bottle shared by emacgee.  Hazy light orange/dark gold pour with white head. Bready nose, big time. Sweet malt. Slightly metallic mild hops, but still more bread. Really just okay and nothing more. Wondered if this was past its freshness.

22oz bottle.   Orange-gold color with a medium sticky white head and lots of sediment at the end.   Aroma of sweet oranges and lots of spicy hops. The finish is very hoppy and bitter but balanced by a pretty big sweetness.   Medium-full body with a lightly mouth-coating texture and medium-intense carbonation.   I really enjoyed this, though the finish could have been dryer.     I think they nailed the hop profile but could probably tweak the malts an bit on the next go around.

No one should ever make an imperial pilsner.  Anyway.  Light orange color and cloudy.  Loads of hops, some saaz I think, which I really love.  Much more like a pale ale than a pilsner, but the strong euro lager category works well also.

Bottle at the Drink for Charity event at Rattle & Hum.  Pours a cloudy amber color.  Smells a little bit of grain and citrus.  Flavors are all sweet plum and prune, with a big alcohol note coming through.  Finishes lightly bitter with even more alcohol.  Far too hot.
Bottle.  Pours a hazy orange body with a thin white head.  Grainy cherry, sweet and etoh latent fruit, really boozy with some light pear notes and more etoh.

22 oz bottle.  Clear yellow brown with a lacy white cap.  Nose is pear, lemon, dough and toffee.  Medium body with light carb; kind of syrupy, cloying.  Taste is concentrated orange Kool-aid, bitter tangerine peel and cantaloupe.  Peppery finish.  By imperializing a pilsner some of the best qualities of the style are lost.  As a strong ale just OK.

Bottle pours gold color with white head.  Aroma on this is awesome!  Pine, citrus, and really hoppy.  Medium mouthfeel.  Flavor is upfront smack you in the face hops, has a touch of caramel sweetness, then finishes with a somewhat unpleasant grainy finish.  Otherwise a solid brew.

From a 22oz Bottle.  Mostly transparent, honey gold colored pour with a thin layer of tight bubbled, fizzy white head.  Aromas of resinous, piney hops.  Some sweet, sugary malt sweetness is also present, along with some moderately high alcohol levels.  The hop aroma smells nice at first, but when combined with the alcohol and malt sweetness, it creates somewhat of a harsh, abrasive sensation.  Medium bodied, softly carbonated mouthfeel with a moderate sweetness.  The malt flavors arent heavy enough to qualify as sticky, but are too sweet to reveal a clean, pilsner malt breadiness.  Hop flavors are bold and resinous, but the crispness of the hop bitterness is disguised by the underlying malt sweetness.  A moderately high level of alcohol comes in on the back end, creating a somewhat harsh finish.  This seems to disrupt the bold hop flavors, as they transition into a brash alcohol finish rather than simply enhance the dryness on the back end.  Enough potential to look forward to future batches.

One extra point in Appearance simply for the bottle.  Awesome.

The taste is a bit more complex than the aroma with more herbal hop kick and booze in the finish.  The bready malts form a solid backbone with some citrus hops kick up front and a sweetness that builds between sips.

The mouthfeel is sticky with good soft carbonation and a body on the heavier side of things.  The alcohol isnt completely hidden, but doesnt dominate.

This is a pretty hefty beer for the style with a strong herbal presence as well as a noticeable alcohol kick.  Its not the most drinkable brew but its tasty.

Bottle and served in my NB Worthy glass: Deep golden hue with a small but lasting frothy with head. Surprisingly really, I expected a boozy mess but instead got a nice strong lager, The Euros should learn something from this.

Bottle. Just realized that I never rated this.

Bottle from City Beer.  The sparkling, honey-colored body is hazy and orange-hued.  This mildly effervescent body is topped with a moderate, if not small head of ivory that sticks in rounded splotches and rings on the walls of my pils glass.  The weight of the beer is masked by ample carbonation and has a soft, semi-dry finish.  I smell the sweet aroma of pils yeast, sugared bread dough, citrus, caramel, and notes of pine.  A nice mixture of malts and hops confront you immediately: pine, citrus, sugar, caramel; then the pils yeast steps in, followed by a bitter finish of pine, citrus, wood, some unknown spice, and a touch of roasted-caramel malt.  Notable alcoholic warmth on the finish as it sits a while, which simply enhances the sweet citrus finish (carries a lot of orange and grapefruit rind) and the pils yeast with roasted caramel.  Take a strong ale composed of the pils yeast and the malts of a bock with a touch of roasted malt, but replace the noble hops with something you might expect in a big West Coast IPA and you have the Panzer.  The Panzer is mellow, but well-hopped, and overly drinkable for its ABV...which is really no problem at all.

Bottle from City Beer Store in San Fran. I am really starting to love this style, hopefully Ill find more good examples soon. Hazy dark yellow pour with a big white head. Smells of grapefruit, lemon, pine and caramel. Big piney hop taste up front with a solid amount of spice (clove, cardamom) and a bit of lemon. Finishes with a nice mix of hop bitterness and malty sweetness. Satisfying brew.

1st off.............man i love american version of euro strong lagers!!!! Great hazy orange pour with a wicked nose of  hops, sweet caramel, caramelized apples, and sweet malt. on tap at lost abbey. pale orange color with fizzy body. fruit spices prominent in the taste.

22oz pours golden with a white head. aroma is fruit with a touch of yeast. mouthful is big and bitter with some bright fruit lighting up the pallet then finishes with some bitter earthy hop flavors. very enjoyable iPil

22oz bottle courtesy of sparky27.  Pours a slightly hazy straw yellow with a good white head.  Nice citrus, grass and resin hop nose.  Great depth of flavors that meld well together. I just love Impy Pils and I wish that more brewers did them.  Hopefully this one makes into the seasonal release rotation for PP, cause I would always buy some.  Thanks for answering my ISO for this one Eric!

Whoa man this really is an imperial pilsner.  They arent joking.  This is a lager?  Pours a slightly hazy golden color with a small white head.  Aroma is grassy hops and grainy pale malts. Sampled at Backus Backyard Bash. Cloudy gold with a thin white head. Fruity nose, resiny pine and hints of pepper. Malty flavors with a light graininess, nice bitter grass and pine. Hell yeah, nice beer!

Small white head, retention is fair with a little spotty lace. Lightly hazy gold hued brew. Nose is grassy, spicey with some bready malt notes, faint citrus. Medium body, somewhat slick on the palate, minerally. Bready and sweet malt flavors under a barrage of stinging hop flavors, co2? Grassy and grainy, sweet and bready. Sweet, hoppy finish with some grapey, berry notes and a biting finish. ABV is well hidden. Thanks to Dirty Martini for the bomber.

Bottle: Thanks Dickinsonbeer! Pours slightly hazy golden with a strong off-white head. Nice nose- some lightly sweet cookie-like malt qualities with lots of spicy noble hop presence. Creamy texture. Flavor is extremely peppery. The sweet cookie-like malt base is covered with spicy noble and a touch of peppery ethanol. Becomes homogeneous. A bit too warm.

Bottle shared by Dickinsonbeer I think. Very hoppy, wonderfully citrus aroma, much lke an IPA, not even close to a pils. Similar flavor, a citrus overload, quite nice but one cant tell how this is supposed to have any pils blood (saaz or lager) in it at all. Fun.I hadnt even heard of this beer until Paul busted it out.

(22oz. bottle, courtesy of Bman1113vr)  Pours a cloudy yellow body with a small white head.  Aroma of grass, floral, grain, and citrus.  Flavor of hops (grass, floral, pine), doughy, and toasted grain.

Poured a slightly hazed light gold color with a thin head.  Hopy aroma that sits on top of a bready malt base.  Notes of alcohol as well.  The malt flavor has a sweet start with a bitter and hoppy long dry finish.  It almost gets to a medium body.

Bomber thanks to Hopdog!  Pours a hazy deep gold/light copper with a nice fluffly white head.  Aroma is sharp earthy spicy and floral hops with a sweet doughy pils backbone but a slight bit dirty overall.  Floral and slight citrus hops a bit on the orange zest side a bit syrupy and a nice harsh tacky bitterness- pretty good but i like SA a bit better oveerall.

Thanks to dickinsonbeer for sharing - semi-hazy gold - man, this is hoppy as hell - huge noble hop bitterness in the nose makes an almost ipa-ish impression - the flavor is big, bitter, and dry, with some residual background sweetness to let you know how strong the beer is - still, fairly clean, with juicy hops that leave the mouth watering - nice.
bottle thanks to bman1113vr.  poured a hazy yellow with a thin white head that fades.  aroma was fruity and floral.  flavor was alcohol and citrus.  medium body.  a very tasty treat.
Bottle. Perfume, good citrus, long cottony after taste, light apple. Medium sweetness, CO2 really comes out. Very nicely done, very drinkable.  An excellent representation of a difficult style.
Bottle thanks to Bman1113vr.  The smell is malts, fruits, carmel, clean, and hops.  The look is hazy, cloudy, and a good golden color.  The taste is malty, clean, grains, caramel, and hops.

Bottle thanks to bman1113vr. Pours a cloudy gold. Aroma is very nice, fruity and hoppy. Flavor is malty, hoppy, with a nice bitterness. Mouthfeel is full body with med-high carbonation. Overall, Tasty and strong!
bottle thanks to bman1113vr, cloudy yellow pour with pineapple aromas and a malty bitter flavor, finishes slightly bitter
Pours a pale yellow.  Grainy, with a light honey flavor and pale malt.  Kind of an uncomfortable finish.

Really strong, really hot, super sweet, syrupy, hopped up and delicious.

Pours a hazy gold color with a foamy head that lasts throughout.  Aroma of caramel malt, yeast and big pine and citrus hops.  Flavor is sweeter than expected, but not overpowering.  Light roasted malt, sweet fruit and yeast give way to a good hoppy finish.  Nearly thick and sticky on the palate.  Very good brew!
Good brew.  Murky yellow pour with a small head and very sticky lacing.  Aroma of pine.  Taste is piney, bready with some soft light fruits.  Crisp on the tongue.  A good thirst quencher.

Bottle. Poured a clear golden-light orange color. The head was thick, creamy, and off white with good retention and lacing. Attractive aroma of pineapple, yeasty bread dough, citrus, noble hops, and hay. Medium to full bodied and slightly sweet with mild to moderate bitterness that cut through the sugars somewhat. Grass, noble hop, and citrus dominated the flavor, but there was also hay, subdued pineapple, and a bit of alcohol. Pretty good, but a bit too bitter for me.

Fresh bomber.  A hazy, glowing, tangerine-gold body is topped with a huge, lasting column of dense, off-white foam.  Sticky flares of lacing mark the glass well.  Aromas of sweet toffee, caramel, and light candy sugar are balanced with ample, bitter, grassy hops.  A hefty dose of creamy, bready pils yeast brings things together on the nose.
