Bready yeast plays a big role, lending that signature pils feel.  Big and sticky on the palate, the sugar content again gets in the way of what could otherwise be a damn fine brew.  As it stands, it is still a pretty tasty concoction.

UPDATED: SEP 4, 2009 22oz bottle, no date from Ledger?s Liquors.  Clear honey golden with a small off-white head, fading to a thick ring and tatttered film.  Aroma of light citrus and floral hops and pear with a nice biscuity clean caramel backbone.  Flavor is much the same with the caramel turning a bit earthy and some spicy alcohol.  Definitely more sweet than a regular pils.  Semi-dry with bitterness peaking around a 4.  Full body with light to moderate prickly carbonation.  Not your typical pils (despite the 9.5% on my label), but still quite tasty.  8-4-8-3-15--3.8  Rerate 9/4/09 @ Blue Palms.  The flavor is a good deal drier this year, and I cant say I notice any caramel at all--definite pasta notes and some light biscuity characteristics are now going on, and I actually dont remember any caramel when I first had this.  Dry slightly alcoholic finish bitterness with alcohol @ a 4-5.  Smells and tastes like a well done imp. pils. Up to a 4.1
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: Bomber poured a clear orange with a lingering ring of ivory foam. Aromas of yeast, bread dough, light fruittiness and ahint of carmel. Palate was medium bodied and crisp with a lightly dry finish. Flavors of carmel, bread, spicy hops and pepper with a crisp warming moderatly bitter finish.
Clear golden with medium white head. Hoppy aroma with citric and malty notes. Flavour is hoppy with citric, grapefruit  and piney notes.Solid bitter finish.

Bottle. Orange amber beer with a cream colored head. Earthy, nice malt, strong noble hop aroma. Malty, caramel flavor with citrus, mineral notes, and light grass. Medium bodied. Sweet caramel lingers with citrus, earth, and light spice. Nice hop complexity, but overall a bit sweet.

Very pale hazy golden beer with a thin white head.  Lightly spicy hop nose and a light spicy hoppiness.  Fairly straightforward light pils malt.  A touch of honeyish sweetness.  Quite sticky and sweet but also with a kiss of spicy hop bitterness and a touch of light fruit.  It’s okay, but it’s a bit on the sweet side.  Nice and clean though.

UPDATED: FEB 11, 2012 Bottles thanks to paiste2002 and hopscotch... Sent in a picture to be uploaded. Pours a hazed electric yellow with a small off-white head that fades quickish. Aroma is very hoppy with tons of grass, floral and herbal qualities and a bit of hay and a nice yeasty note. The hops make me smile, and are very nice and floral. Taste is floral nearly citrusy hops with a bit of melon, hay and caramel. Syrupy, but also lightly tingly bubbles. Quite refreshing but yet still strong. Albeit Ports First bottled lager, it is still an awesome beer which lives up to the name.

22oz bottle. Pours hazy golden color, capped with a small white head. Hoppy aroma, with pine, grapefruit, honey, ginger and tropical fruit. Sweet up front, with some honey and malt, which are soon joined by citric and floral hops. Hops and grain hang on for a lengthy finish.  Big hops, backed up by big malt.

22 oz. bottle from Plaza Liquors - Pours a hazy golden color with a 3/4 finger thick off white head.  Very light lacing.  Aroma is pine, citrus, and floral hops and a touch of toasty malt.  The flavor is like an American Pale ale.  Hops and lightly sweetened malt.   Medium body.  I was expecting more of a European style Pils.  Overall, a very good beer.

UPDATED: SEP 21, 2009 Bomber from Stan at Lone Hill.  Aroma is very thick with gummy, stalwart Euro hops and caramel.  Flavor is much the same, but ends much sweeter than Sam Adams Imperial Pils.  If there were such a thing as Malt Hops, they would be used here.  Toasted cinnamon apple outline the flavor and aroma.  Tap version is even better.

Pours a transparent bright golden with a clingy-lacing froth of white head.  Aroma of fresh resiny grapefruity hops and some pale malty sweetness.  Body starts with good fullness for the style and a good maltiness with tons of assertive juicy citrusy hops before a crisp, bittersweet finish.  Did not really remind me much of a pilsner, but more of an imperial pale ale. Regardless of style designation, it was pretty tasty.

hazy shade of orange/golden brownish with a bunch of yeast clumps floating around. it*s capped by a soapy/rocky off white head which leaves lots of descending rings of lace and an enormous amount of spots. 

all kinds of citrus in the aroma!... grapefruit, lemon, lemon grass, ginger, peach, orange, a touch of caramel, some earthy spice and grassy fresh juicy hops fill the profile. 

the palate is sweet but not overly (especially given the 9.4%) while dry and hoppy at the same time. flavors are of wood, grass, earthy spice, malty sweetness/caramel, loads of citrus and their piths with a dry punchy hoppy finish. alcohol is noticed as it warms. it is full bodied but green hoppiness keeps it from becoming cloying. smooth, soft and slick textures from a nice mix of carbonation.

this starts incredibly spicy/citrusy/hoppy on the palate and mid-palate when cold but fades and gets a bit "dead" just before it is swallowed as it warms. that*s a negative for me given the fact that this is definitely a sipper...
9/5/8/4/16/4.2

Bomber. Fruity and yeast aroma. Gold body with white head. Lacing stuck like a sugar inside pint glass. Good citrus zestty flavor along with some mild dry bittering. Citrus fruity aftertaste left on the palate. Good refreshing beer.

This golden ale poured into a pilsner glass with a beautiful fluffy white head and a flowery aroma. That head just would not go away. There is a rich caramel malt base with a crisp hop laden bitter finish. Lots of floaties at the bottom.
Courtesy of Guerde.  Hazy gold color with no head.  Light citrus aroma.  Lightly bitter taste, without being floral, citrusy, piney or anything else.  A little caramel malt.  Slightly corny.

bottle courtesy of stefanje.  Pours cloudy yellow with a scant white head.  The aroma is grassy, but there is a considerable amount of citrus peel smells as well.  I failed to pick up any of the bread or cracker aromas characteristic of pilsners.  The flavor is also very sweet upfront, with some mandarin orange and light vanilla, rounding out to a bitter grapefruit peel finish.  This is much thicker than most pilsners, and it is just alright.

22 oz. bottle - also sampled on draft at the LA Sinner/Saint party; pours clear orange with spotty white head; dry, wheaty, bready, cloves and some lemon; sweet and quite bitter; i remember this being much smoother on draft; drinks bitter, dry with a crisp maltiness; i love the aromas, but way too bitter for me

22oz bottle courtesy of Dogbrick.  Pours a clear gold with no head.  Aroma is not so great - smells like a pale lager with a bit of yeast.  Flavor is balanced yeast and hop like a Belgian IPA.  Not what I expect from this style.

22oz bottle. Grassy nose with with some hints of citrus zest. Plenty malty. Bread dough and crust. Slightly crackery. Malt fades and citrus opens as the beer warms. Pours a clear, light copper with a frothy white head. Nonexpressive and just plain bitter hops with lots of grainy malt on the tongue. The alcohol is quite assertive. Cut grass and piney hops. Really not coming together all that well. Full bodied for this style with an astringent and boozy finish. Krampus was a hell of a lot better. Thanks Sebastian!

Sampled from 22-oz bomber and shared by Guerde. Pours a semi-hazy golden burnt brew with an average white head that has some nice retention. Aroma of citrus and grapefruit zest, touch of tropical fruit, golden grain malt, and some floral hops. Taste is full bodied, with flavors of mild golden grain malt, grapefruit, floral hops a touch of earthy spice and some peach. Finish has a mild citrus hop and golden grain aftertaste that has a thick texture that lingers after the finish.

Bottle. Pours dark golden with thin white head. Aroma is leafy hop, light citrus fruit, orange and pineapple, mild graininess in the background. Flavor has very miild malt sweetness, assertive citrus-like hop flavors throughout, oiliness from the hop resin, lots of bitterness in the aftertaste, as well as light astringency. Not exactly my favorite, but a very interesting creation, a lager that showcases some outstanding hop flavors.
Pours hazy blond with a white head.  Nice citrus hop aroma.  Well balanced.  Hops and spice beat the malt, but it was a very solid beer.

Dirty, cloudy orange yellow with a thin white head.   Wow...big chunks of yeast floating around. Sweet malt aroma. Citrus, malt and bitter hops.  Finishes with nothing but hop bitterness. Ugly looking, but a pretty good, simple beer.

This poured a hazy deep golden in color with a moderate white head that dissipated slowly.  The nose was filled with aromas of citrus, honey, and wheat.  In the mouth it was dense and concentrated with great carbonation to keep it very well-balanced.  While not extremely complex, it was very enjoyable with a touch of sweetness in the midpalate.

Bottle, courtesy of alexanderj.  Yellowish amber pour with some white head.  Aroma is sweet fruity malt, grainy malt, and citrus and floral hops.  Floral, citrus, and bittering hops and spices dominate the flavor, yet there is still some very sweet malt underneath.  Maybe the alcohol is noticable, or it is very peppery spices.

UPDATED: AUG 26, 2009 One of my favorite breweries, but not crazy about this one. Pours bright golden orange with a two finger eggshell colored head. The nose is Floral and yeast with substantial spice notes. The flavor has some hop bitterness but a more present spiciness overwhelms. Lasting spice.

Thanks to Shyam for sharing.  Pours a hazy golden color from the bomber with a noticeable amount of sediment.  Hefty for an Imperial Pils with heavy amoutns of yeast and floral hops.  A very tasty brew.
Bottle at home - Thanks Sune - Shared with Mette & Sune. High hoppy, grassy, candy, sweetness, white sugar, cactus, orange, citrus, peachy, vingummi, sharpness. Nice bitterness.

Thanks to Axilla for sharing this one.  Pours a hazy golden with a bubbly/creamy white head.  Aroma was a lot of lemon zest, leafy hop notes, bready pilsner malt and hop profile showcased nicely.  Aroma of candy citrus notes, grainy, floral really nice hop character and iced tea.

Surprise bottle via Stefanje the recidivist of generousity!  Oh my weary bones!  Theres an old farmers shed down the road up ahead, thats where Ill rest my weary bones....with a bottle of this semi hazy, apricot lookin stuff. nose is of watery fruit mixed with some whole hops.  Head settles fast.Fruit strts the mouthfeel but is quickly overtaken by hop bitterness.  not a blitzkrieg of ops but a certainty of it. Alcohol is surpisingly well hidden for such a light medium body. kes me feel like singin..... Well...Theres a rabbit  in the log and I aint got no dog! How will I get him?  I know!  Ill set out a bowl of this stuff!   It aint zactly pils but its still good.

Bottle at T&M’s. Dennis, toncatcher traded me this one. Thanks! Pours a clear golden with a small white head. Smells just like any other lager. Quite bitter with strong hops aromas. Hints of guldøl. Also some caramel notes. Bitter finish. Good.

Bottle from spark-dog-two-seven! Thanks E! Poured into a lager glass. Small head, golden yellow color. Aroma of light hops, maybe some light fruits as well. Decent lacing left on the glass. Taste is sweet, which kind of threw me off-guard... Not sugary sweet though. A nice touch of hops to balance it out. Crisp taste as well. The texture is average, easy to drink. Decent beer.
22oz bottle. Dark gold pour with a whie head. Crisp clean malty aroma. Pretty tasty, nice bitterness in the finish.
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA

text: 22oz bottle. pours hazy orange with white head. nose is sweet oranges, mango, and fruit. flavor is sweet mango, grapefruit, piney, with very astringent bitterness. i enjoyed the first bottle but hated the second so I’m not sure if there was a consistency issue but this just seemed to do too much.

22 oz. bottle.  Pours a mostly clear gold with a moderate foamy white head that lasted through three-quarters of the glass and left ample lace.  Very mild malt in the aroma along with some stronger grapefruit.  The flavor up front is considerably more malty than the aroma suggests, follwed by a healthy dose of grapefruit flavor and bitterness.  The bitterness grows and borders on astringent at its peak and lingers briefly after the swallow.  Good stuff.

Poured a hazy dark golden color with a small, white head that left nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma of citrus fruits, floral hops, toasted malts, toffee, and pine.  Taste of more toast, toffee, citrus fruits, pine, light alcohol, and medium bitterness.

Sampled on 11/17/08. This Imperial Pilsner pours a deep orange gold color from a 22oz bottle. Small to medium sized white/beige foamy head with nice lacing. The aroma is herbal, floral, fruity and sweet. A medium to full bodied Imperial Pilsner. The malts are fruity and sweet. The hops are floral and a touch grapefruity. This beer is very hoppy for a pilsner, it would be hoppy for a lot of IPAs! It still has that spicy crisp character of a pilsner, but the hops just blow it out. Yet, it is fairly well balanced. Lively carbonation. Pretty much hide the 9.5% alcohol, except for a touch at the finish. Mouthfeel is full. Finish is clean and crisp. Aftertaste is slightly bitter.

A bit odd. Aroma: very grainy, not too much in terms of hops. Flavor: odd, lots of sweet grainy malt, with a weird hop character. Too sweet really. Somewhat like the SA Hallertau Imp Pils in that it has an ice tea fruity tobacco-y character. Shows it’s alcohol a little bit in the mouthfeel. Very low carbonation, too low. The extended finish is better.

Draft @ Lost Abbey.  Pours a slightly oranged yellow color; thin white head with patchy fine-bubbled lacing.  Solid amounts of earthy, oily bitterness in the aroma; significant, but slightly muted hop presence; oily, slightly hot.  Medium-to-full mouthfeel: loads of dense, oily earthy hops and sticky candy sugar malts beneath; dense, messy, slightly old beer.  Lengthy finish: toasty malts, honey sweet malts; reasonably balanced end.

22oz bottle shared courtesy of axilla (thanks!). Poured a medium and hazy golden color with a small sized white head. Aromas of wheatiness, citrus rinds, spices, and grassy. Tastes of citrus, grassy, and some spices. Medium alcohol burn in the finish.

Bottle from South Bay Drug. Orange (!) color with a slight creamy white head. Nice fruit aroma. Medium body with near creamy carbonation. Flavor is fruit, with some spicy hop, and it finishes with funk hints. Mouth watering.

Sample at the Columbus Ratebeer gathering at ogglethorps 11/20/08: Bottle from the Solana Beach location. The beer pours a clear pale orange color with a medium thin and foamy oww-white head that diminishes steadily. Stringy lacing. Aroma of peppery hops and mild malt. Light, crisp body with flavors of floral hops, pepper and sweet malt. The finish is moderately bitter hops with a lingering peppery aftertaste. Overall this is an interesting hybrid but I did not enjoy it as much as I expected I would.

This beer is just classic in all the sense of the word. Brilliant deep golden yellow color with a solid head that lingers. excellent aromatics push sweet crisp malt forward. Full nectar with brilliant effers creating a soft and luscious mouthfeel. A dense malt backbone with a defined sweetness factor is instantly balanced by a crisp hop component. The sweetness is overcome effortlessly reminding the user to take the next sip. Despite its density it is unbelievably drinkable. This specimen is by far more refined than other of this pedigree. Excellent! Trump!

Bomber poured a clear orange with a lingering ring of ivory foam. Aromas of yeast, bread dough, light fruittiness and ahint of carmel. Palate was medium bodied and crisp with a lightly dry finish. Flavors of carmel, bread, spicy hops and pepper with a crisp warming moderatly bitter finish.

What is not to like about this beer.  Pours bright, cloudy gold with an exploding white head.  The usual clove, spice, and grass, are here, but with mango, pepper, and herbs from the added hops.  Creamy, smooth mouthfeel.  The sweet lagery tastes blend well with the hops.  More clove and bananas in the flavor along with a little grapefruit and tangerine that breaks through the Saaz-like notes.  Maybe this will spark a Cali-Pils crossover akin to the Belgian-Cali IPA.
Bomber from South Bay shared by Odeed; Thanks Jake;hazy orange with a very small offwhite head; Nose of steamed brocolli and spices; flavor is light bitterness, caramel, ginger, and corriander.
Cloudy golden yellow, citrus, grassy, hoppy, little grainy, little malty, dry finish.

Pours with a frothy, initially three finger thick, light tan colored head the is held up by a persistent carbonation.  The beer is a lightly copper tinged, deep gold color that shows brilliantly clear, bright gold color when held up to the light.  The aroma is definitely hop focused, though perhaps not quite as whack you in the head expressive as I thought it was going to be (and this is not necessarily a bad thing).  Grassy and lightly herbal up front, the aroma finishes with a fruity tropical fruit note that is a mix of mango, kumquat, lychee and sweet orange zest.  Quite a bit of cracker-like grain character contributes a nice malt profile.

Lightly sweet up front, but soon picks up a nice herbal hop note that turns towards bitter, but then piquantly fruity in the long finish.  I have never had a hoppy beer get bitter and then fruity in the finish; it is quite interesting that the tropical fruit notes are what lingering on the palate.  Up front the herbal hops contribute an almost peppery bite that is something a bit like arugula, with all the sharp herbal note one would expect.  The fruity hop notes are also noticeable up front, it is just that they mix in with the herbal hop notes so are not quite as prominent.  The hop fruit notes lean towards lychee, ripe peach, kumquat and citrus oil, but they intermix quite well with the previously mentioned herbal notes as well as hints of hemp oil, raw-herbal notes and a touch of chive.

I like that this has the crisp character and herbal hop notes of typical Pilsner, yet it has that something else in the background with the fruity hop character that is not so typical.  This is definitely interesting, more quaffable than beer of this strength should be yet (which is good for something with the name Pilsner on the label) with a certain heft and definite palate presence.  Not as abrasive as double IPA; I was expecting this to be more harshly hoppy, but it is not and this is quite nice.  This is actually really good and I am kicking myself all the more that I somehow missed out on Tovarish at GABF.

Bottle from Joey.  Poured a cloudy gold with a decent white head.  Aroma of hoppy, bitter, fruity.  Very unique.  Taste is hoppy citrus, pine, grass, some malt.  Nice beer.  Finish is bitter.  Mouth is full and coating.  Some mild carbonation.  Overall, another unique offereing from Port.

22oz from South Bay - thanks, Joey! Goofy label and concept, but whatever. Looks and pours like a DIPA, cloudy, moderate carb, just a tad like Port 2nd (though more body). The nose is far more citric than Id imagined, with strong hints of the sweet, soft tangerine. Body is moderately lively, and the beer is very well hopped. Bitters everywhere in the mouthfeel, dominating while still leaving room for the softer qualities. Long dry finish. One of the better examples of the style.

Pours a very light gold in color.  There is a huge fluffy head on the pour.
Smell is very hoppy.  More than you would expect from a pils.  Flavor is very nice.  Very crisp, clean and aggressively hopped.  I’m really enjoying this beer.  Good flavor and very inviting to drink.
Nice yeasty lagerish aroma at first. Pours cloudy amber with white fluffy head. Nose is bananas and HOPS. Oh god, wonderful, floral aromatic hops! Bitter finish, but remarkably balanced.

On tap at Lost Abbey for the Saints and Sinners party. Pours a clear, dark gold with  a white ring. Sharp aroma, very grassy, of malt and spices. Taste is quite bitter, of malt, pine hops, herbs, and grass. Lingering bitterness. Tasty.

Split a 22oz bomber between me, myself and I tonight. I’ve wanted to try this since I hear it was on tap for a limited time at beachwood. Julian makes some fantastic brews, and this is no exception.

It pours murky orange and almost looks like a hefe. The aroma is what first jumps out at me. Wow! This beer seems pretty freshly bottled and I can definitely smell the hops, pine and maybe some grapefruit/citrus.

Flavorful. Tastes like it smells.  At the end of the day, it’s a solid brew, very drinkable. And before I knew it, all gone.

Bottle from Sparky27. Thanks Eric! Huge aroma of malt and hops. Strong bread, grass, pepper, and earthy hops. Alcohol as well. Pours a hazy golden initially with a fantastic head and sticky lacing. The second half of the bomber renders suspended yeast and a milky golden beverage. Hops smash your face throughout the flavor of this one, and I love it. There is a substantial amount of bready malts. Grass, pepper, floral hops. Intensely bitter and sticky. Alcohol leaves its presence known. I think this one put me to sleep shortly there after. Gotta love Port and there liberal use of hops. Has to be the best of the style that I have ever had. I really liked this one.

Port produced another winner with this one.   Bottle acquired via Sparky27...Eric, thanks again for the bottle!!!  Beautiful crystal clear 14-karat pour if careful with lively carbonation.  The 1/4 inch ivory head leaves perfect little ringlets around the glass upon every sip.  Aroma is yeast, biscuit, and malty sweetness.  Flavor is freshly picked tangerines and orange zest.  Second pour produces significantly hazier results.  Alcohol is somewhat noticeable because of it’s youth and definitely warms the belly.  Wish this was more readily available!!!  Eric, thanks again!!!

Bottle Lightly hazy, light golden lager with a mid-sized, frothy, white head. Excellent retention. Boozy, fruity aroma with hints of resin and white pepper. Full-bodied with a slick mouthfeel and lively carbonation. Harsh metallic bitterness up front, but, as it warms, the malt kicks in, the hops back down a notch, and everything seems to come together and round out. Lengthy, scorchingly bitter finish. Too hopped up for my palate, but a quality brew and probably a hop heads wet dream.

Murky amber with a tight white head. Big yeasty, boozy, lager grain aromas. Medium/full body with a frothy mouthfeel. Heavy sweet yeasty pale malt flavors actually works well in this beer.  I will be back for more !
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: Bottle from padrefan98, thanks a ton Jon!  Poured a deep, bright orange color with a moderate white head that faded to a soapy layer that left some lacing.  Are of sweet citrus (tangerine, clementine, and light lemon), some flowery hops, and some light pine resin.  Sweet, lightly tart fruity entry with hints of tangerine and peach leads into a moderate hoppy bitterness with some leafy, resinous flavor with undertones of orange and pine.   Moderate carbonation, smooth and full on the palate.  Really an awesome beer, regardless of what style it’s categorized as.  Thanks again Jon!

Light golden colored brew with a head that fades into a collared ring around the liquid.  Bold hop nose stinks of spruce, grapefruit, weeds and lemon rind, but it only smells of hops.  Super bold hops in the taste, with delicious notes of pine, lemon, resin and fresh herb.  Basically a pretty tasty, massively hopped and bitter lager.  Intensely hopped, basically a Double IPA.

Pours a cloudy copper into a tulip. Minimal head dissolves quickly into a thin collar with light, spotty lacing. Huge hop nose, more on the earthy/piney side, but some fruityness shows through. Hops dominate the palate as well, pine and spice. Caramel sweetness is noted, but it seems to lean too far to the hop side. Medium bodied, and a shorter finish than expected, considering the strength. Much lighter and more crisp than a comparable DIPA, which ups the drinkability.

A fine beer, and an interesting DIPA alternative. A must-try for any port lover or hophead, but I think it lacks a bit in balance.

22oz bottle pours orange with a soapy white head.  Orange, lemon malts, yeast, and touch of noble hops in the aroma.  Sweet malts, citrus with fresh hops and grassy bitter finish.  Slightly bitter and sweet for a pils, but a good beer.

22oz bottle thanks to andrew (again!).... pours a cloudy orange brown and a thin soapy white head.....aroma of smarties somewhat medicinal, and sweet citrus notes...flavors of pineapple juice and quite a bit of bitterness to it in the finish.  medium carbonation.  not totally drinkable for me but still pretty decent.

Tasting at the McBackus Backyard Bash. Cloudy light gold orange pour. Malty citrus hop aroma, interesting hop choice for a lager. Taste is hop bitter with a nice malt balance. Very smooth and drinkable.

Bottle. Pours a pale light orange with some good bubble action. Very honeydew and pineapple in the nose. Muscat grape, pineapple flavors. Light body, oily texture. l Pretty dry and sticky finish. Really good beer. A nice change of pace for me!

different than I was expecting....some tangeriney hops on the nose....
very drinkable...but different than the hops that I was expecting.....
panty dropper for sure!
Pours orange/ogl, kinda hazy. Aroma is hops, malt, and fruit. All are on the subtle side. Flavor is hops, malt, fruit, and yeast. Ends on the dry side, and a little bitter.

22oz bottle from Bevs for Less.  Pours a clear golden yellow with a frothy white head, great lacing.  Nose was not quite as hoppy as expected, a bit on the sweet side.  Flavor is where the hops came into play.  Finish is bold with some hop bitterness.

Pours a hazy orangeish copper with a soapy head. Aroma of hops, some fruity notes, malt and citrus. Flavor is big citrusy hops almost like a IPA, yeast, a lot of malt sweetness, fruity notes, a lot of bitterness balanced out with sweetness in the finish. Best imperial Pilsner i’ve ever had, I enjoyed this one quite a bit.

UPDATED: SEP 1, 2009 Bottle, from Windmill Farms.  Nice golden color, Smell is nice floral hops.   Flavor is incredibly sweet, hoppy, with a lingering medicinal aftertaste.  Too sweet for me, but I am glad that Port is trying something different.  Would like to see a non-imperial pilsener bottled.

Bomber from Windy City. Bottle read 9.5%. Medium orangish color. Sweet fruity nose, with a strong hop presence. Full mouthfeel. Slightly sweet up front. Some dry yeatiness. Finish is strong bitter hoppiness. Solid hopped up pils.

aroma is almost like stale hops (almost like bacon) with some background of orange citrus.  Pours clear light amber.  Flavor begins crisp and sweet with hints of honey.  Finishes with an intense hoppiness.  Drinkability is medium to low.  Not my favorite, aroma seemed a little off.  LA should stick to Ales!

i dont find pils that I like very much...well this one I loved.  A golden pour leads to a boquet of honey, spice, malt and some hops.  Flavor is balanced, bright and delicious.  Smooth is the perfect word for this beer.  Some good juicy hops finish this beer perfectly.  Well crafted.

Bomber poured into chilled pint glass. Aroma is sweet with some honey and spicy fragrances. Appearance is orange/amber much like the earlier Fresh Hop Tide I drank. Flavor, this is very unique and a very creative expression. Palate is sweet but smooth and the alcohol is probably hidden in the balanced sweetness. 

A very cool new style of beer for me. Id buy it again!

22 oz bottle from Holiday.  Rating this from memory, and will rerate soon, as I want to drink another.  It was sweeter than  Iexpected, but in a light, clear way.  Lots of sweet and spices, but also hoppy.  Bright dense head that hung around.  I expected good, and the beer was better than that.  Look forward to tasting when  Ican take specific notes.
On tap at the Saint/Sinner Dinner.  Pours golden yellow with a small white head.  Aroma of citrus and hops.  Flavors were hops and some malt.  Very nice.
Draft at the Sinner’s party.   Citrus and hoppy on the aromas with more hops in the flavor.  Very viscous and full in the mouth.  Nice finish of citrus hops.  Very nice beer.

Tap @ Lost Abbey during the Saint’s and sinner’s party.  Pours orange with a bright white ring.  Nose is light and hoppy.  Taste is really damn nice, a sweet and hoppy pils with tons of taste, nice work julian.
Tasted at the Sinner party.  Yellow with a fluffy white head.  Very nice fruity aroma and taste with some mellow alcohol notes . Quite good.

UPDATED: OCT 19, 2008 22oz bottle. This beer rules! Pours brilliant, clearish amber with a medium sized white head, some lace. Smells mellow, light and sweet malty... unassuming. Tastes unbelievably citrusy with just enough aggressive malt sweetness to call it a pilsner. Think bright and sweet hoppy triple ipa only bottom fermented. Bright resiny, orange and lemon with a little bit of melon. FUll body, dry and bitter astringent, good carbonation.

UPDATED: SEP 5, 2009 650 ml bottle from Bev4less. Pours a cloudy dark yellow with a small off-white head. Lots of floatie chunks in the bottom of the bottle. The aroma is complex with sweet breads, yeast, allspice a touch of citrus and alcohol.  The flavor is a bit confused--this beer does not know if it want s to be a sweet beer or a hoppy beer. There are strong elements of both, also in the taste I get peanuts, allspice, oranges and again there is that bit of alcohol. The mouthfeel is well balanced and malty. The finish is long with lingering sweet hops. Overall: A very original brew. Very addictive. Recommended.

Bomber.  Pours a cloudy gold with some floaters and a one finger dense white head that results in spotty lacing.  Nose is sweet citrus, biscuity yeast and malt.  Taste is sweet malt and yeast upfront with ripe tangerines and oranges coming into play.  Some alcohol spiked grapefruit finishes it out and the tartness lingers for quite awhile.  Medium, creamy mouth feel.  I liked this a lot.

bottle from PPs Shop in Carlsbad: funny label! aroma unlike expectations; hard, sweet, yeasty, and hot; banana, peach, mango--tropical essence, i assume; good and oddly smooth--hard, but quaffable; i liked it a lot.

Bottle from Pacific Park Market in Aliso Viejo.
Hazy golden pour with a white head. Nice aroma and a complex flavor. This was easy drinking. The abv was well-hidden and snuck up on me later

Bottle from South Bay Drugs.  Poured a rich, light amber/dark ruddy gold.  Off white head.  Aroma of yeast, almost belgian, sweet malt, bread; herbal/spice.  Agree completely with wetherel’s description of the aroma a few ratings below.  Flavor was sweet and pretty hot still.  alcohol wasn’t overly detracting however.  I’m not an expert of the style, but this doesn’t seem like an example of it.  Still it was pretty tasty.  The hop flavor could have been tastier, but the sweet, sugary malt was enjoyable.  Prefer the Sam Adams version, but this was still good.

UPDATED: OCT 20, 2008 22 oz bottle from Beverages 4 Less in Santee. Some yeast and sweetness. A little dry and boozy. But good none the less. Another home run by Port. I mean who else does an imperial pilsner? The day was perfect for this. No work on a hot blustery fall like day in Southern California. 

Re-Rate- Met the maker of this recipe. A guy named Julian dubbed the best Brewer nobody knows by Mr. T. Arthur of Port Brewing. I also sampled some of Julians home brews. The Sour he had was excellent. How does a homebrewer produce a sour that blows away most proffesionals? Somebody get this guy into the business. I have had the pilsner several times now and I believe this style needs more representatives.

Tasted from tap at Lost Abbey.  Yellow amber color.  Interesting aroma.  Kind of like it has corriander in it, or it’s brewed at high temps, or a saison yeast or something.  Unexpected in a pilsner, but an imperial pilsner...maybe.  No skunky Saaz. Sweet.  Easy to drink.  Good.   I’m not sure if imperial pilsner describes the beer well.

UPDATED: FEB 26, 2009 Really solid brew.  Strong lager is noted?  Seemed more like an Ale.  Great aroma, strong pils flavor and Germanesk.  Lots of minerals and a strong rustic and bitter finish.  After this opened up it was more intense.  These would benefit from 6-12 months of bottle age.  Tried from Bomber.

Update, enjoyed bottle 2 with 4 moths of age, drinking at its peak, the little bit of bottle age helped this really come around.  Score improves and this felt like a german beer brewed in germany.  outstanding!

Sampled from the tap at Port Brewing on Friday night . The perfect way to celebrate the end of the week and start the weekend. The boyz were busy bottling and holding down the fort while the rest were at GABF,so we had the hard task of sampling this brew. Golden in color with a thin white head. Subtle citrus aroma. Medium resin like body with some enticing carbonation. Great flavor of bitter hops and balanced complex maltiness. Very long finish with lasting flavor in your mouth. Excellent beer no doubt!!!
